name: Artisal Gold mining, Nyakaziba  Village, Bihanga Subcounty, Bushenyi District
one_sentence: Artisanal gold mining activities using almagamation sorting are done close to the highly saturated valley that drains into the nearby wetland system, contaminating the water system with mercury.
description: Nyakaziba small scale mining is located in Nyakaziba  Village in Bihanga Subcounty in Bushenyi District. Mining is done in a hilly area at the footslopes. All activities such as almagamation sorting are done close to the highly saturated valley that drains  into the nearby wetland system at footslope in undulating terrain. It is estimated that approximately 40 households (200 people including Children and women)  are involved in this activity. The operations typically rely on rudimentary methods and technology and are usually performed by miners who lack economic capital. Mercury- gold amalgamations is an inexpensive, efficient and simple gold extraction method; it is the most common method employed in this area.  It is approximated that this process results in the discharge of large amounts of mercury and other contaminants into the adjacent aquatic ecosystems and the downstream environment.                Mine tailings and spills, particularly the amalgamation activity and sorting, in the areas are a significant sources of pollutants. These contaminate the adjacent water sources and spread into further environments.
health_impact: A number of heavy metals are located in this area. However, mercury is the most important. It produces a second tier political - ecological issue. It has not give the attention it deserves, which makes the tracing of its health impact on the population  very difficult. Mercury and its associated ecological and health effects are abstract, diffuse, and complex. It has many effects on human health, which are dependent on the chemical composition, pathways of exposure, length of exposure, and the individual organism exposed. Considering that the mercury pollution cycle is difficult to explain and its toxic effects are challenging, there has been no country attempt to determine the detrimental level of Mercury to the population.  Health impacts of other the metals has not being traced due in part to the fact that these areas are located in very remote areas with extremely limited accessibility and  limited infrastructure which is a disincentive for detailed research.
notes: The mining areas are also at the periphery of the county borders deep in remote setting. This constrains any attempt by the central authority to under take studies.
strategy: Trainer local trainners to disseminate infomation on technology to artisanal miners regarding gold processing and mercury.Use, aternative technologies available to assist in the reduction of mercury use and release, alternative mercury free gold extration technologies and strategies to improve gold recovery. Acquire and build demonstration units within the mining sites  applying affordable and local technologies for improved gold processing while minimising/ avoiding mercury use/ release
remediation_plan: Eliminate whole ore almalgamation through the introduction of mercury free concentration prior to amalagation-UNEP and Local Environment agency 2- Reduce mercury losses during amalgamation of concentrates through the introduction of closed circiut process(mercury is recycled)- UNEP- UNIDO and NEMA 3-Elimnate the burning of mercury without the use of retorts to contain emissions and assist in recycling and introduce mercury free mining practices where feasible, particularly ore concentrations techniques that preclude mercury use- UNEP , UNIDO NEMA
barriers: The area is very remote, the mining activties scattred, and the community are hostile to outsiders, this might makes accessing for remediation activities very difficult.
local_champ: The National Environment Managment Authority and Uganda Cleaner Production Centre

name: Gualconda Mine, Nariño - apparent soil contamination by tailings with mercury
one_sentence:
Gualconda Mine located in the municipality of Los Andes, near the municipal capital of Sotomayor, is a site where gold has been extracted since 1975 applying mercury as a blending technique. For more than 3 decades, sludge with mercury has accumulated less than 3 meters from the Honda creek, this being the main source of water consumption of nearby homes. The soil where the tailings have accumulated seems to be affected and a strong metallic smell is perceived especially in the areas with the highest accumulation of sludge. The main pollutant is mercury, the migration route is caused by the accumulation of tailings that fall into the ravine and that in times of rain water currents are created that drain directly to the ravine. The main route of exposure is by ingestion of water from the creek which is a source of consumption of the surrounding population and by inhalation of particulate material by exposure of mining tailings with mercury and other pollutants in the open.  

Mina Gualconda ubicada en el municipio de Los Andes, cerca a la cabecera municipal de Sotomayor, es un sitio en el que se ha realizado extracción de oro desde 1975 aplicando mercurio como técnica de amalgamiento. Por más de 3 décadas se han acumulado lodos con mercurio a menos de 3 metros de la quebrada Honda, siendo esta la principal fuente de consumo de agua de viviendas aledañas. El suelo donde se han acumulado los relaves parece afectado y se percibe un fuerte olor metálico especialmente en las áreas con mayor acumulación de lodos. El principal contaminante es mercurio, la  ruta de migración se origina por la acumulación de relaves que caen a la quebrada y que en épocas de lluvia se crean corrientes de agua que drenan directamente a la quebrada. La principal vía de exposición es por ingestión del agua de la quebrada la cual es una fuente consumo de población aledaña y por inhalación de material particulado por exposición de relaves mineros con mercurio y otros contaminantes a la intemperie.
description: The Gualconda mine is located in the municipality of Los Andes in the department of Nariño. The mine is located in a mountainous area, it has a strongly undulating topography with an inclined slope. Tons of tailings with mercury have been deposited on the site for more than 4 decades. A part of the tailings has been contained in sacks, but another important fraction has been dispersed in piles in a sensitive area, very close to the Honda ravine. In the piles of tailings that were deposited on the bank of the ravine, the trace of the fall of these wastes towards the body of water is observed. The tailings are not covered, generating large discharges in times of rain and important ponds that re-transform the tailings into muds (liquids) of difficult handling which leads to drainage processes towards the ravine and the interior soil profiles. The contamination has spread to more than one medium, that is, a source of water and surroundings of the area with vegetation that has been partially eroded. In addition, the natural soil surface has been modified by a compacted soil, full of tailings. In the tailings sedimentation tank there is a strong metallic smell. The Honda ravine is the main source of water consumption for 20 families in summer and at least 200 families use it for irrigation of their agriculture. Less than 2 years ago, the workers of the Gualconda mine moved the sifted ore to their homes and in the kitchen they carried out the smelting of gold, which still contained traces of mercury. According to the results of the XRF, a high concentration of lead and arsenic is presented as secondary metals that are extracted in the mercury amalgam mining process. Draws attention to the high concentrations of As, Pb and Hg in the Honda ravine and in areas around the vegetation and fruit trees.  La mina Gualconda se localiza en el municipio de los Andes del departamento de Nariño. La mina está ubicada en zona montañosa, posee una topografía fuertemente ondulada con pendiente inclinada. En el sitio se han depositado por más de 4 décadas toneladas de relaves con mercurio. Una parte de los relaves se ha contenido en sacos, pero otra fracción importante se ha dispersado en montones en una zona sensible, muy cerca de la quebrada Honda. En los montones de relaves que se depositaron a la orilla de la quebrada se observa la huella de caída de estos residuos hacia el cuerpo de agua. Los relaves no están cubiertos, generando grandes vertimientos en épocas de lluvia y encharcamientos importantes que re-transforman los relaves en lodos (líquidos) de difícil manejo lo cual conlleva a procesos de drenaje hacia la quebrada y los perfiles interiores del suelo.  La contaminación se ha esparcido a más de un medio, esto es, fuente de agua y alrededores de la zona con vegetación que se ha erosionado parcialmente. Además la superficie natural del suelo se ha modificado por un suelo compactado, lleno de relaves. En el tanque de sedimentación de relaves se presenta un olor fuertemente metálico. La quebrada Honda es la principal fuente de consumo de agua para 20 familias en épocas de verano y al menos 200 familias la usan para irrigación de su agricultura.  Hace menos de 2 años, los trabajadores de la mina Gualconda, trasladaban el mineral cernido hacia sus hogares y en la cocina realizaban la fundición de oro, la cual contenía aún trazas de mercurio.  De acuerdo a los resultados del XRF se presenta una concentración elevada de plomo y arsénico como metales secundarios que se extraen en el proceso de minería con amalgama de mercurio. Llama la atención las elevadas concentraciones de As, Pb y Hg en la quebrada Honda y en zonas alrededor de la vegetación y arboles frutales.

name: Desert Locust Control Organisation (DLCO) site, Ayaha Valley, Hargeisa, Somaliland
one_sentence: In the late 1980s, the former DLCO storage site  was bombed, releasing POPs, principally dieldrin and lindane (HCH). The soil is now heavily contaminated and people have still not been evacuated from homes near the site.
description: During the Somali civil war in the late 1980s the Somaliland city of Hargeisa was extensively bombed from the air.  During this time the Desert Locust Control Organisation (DLCO) site near the city was also bombed and largely destroyed.  At that time it is reported that around 81,000 litres of various pesticides that were stored at the site leaked or were deliberately tipped on to the ground during subsequent looting.  The following pesticides were believed to have been stored at the site at that time: aldrin/dieldrin, hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH, BHC or lindane), and fenitrothion.  The former storage site covers an area 100m x 90m and is now almost fully enclosed by a 3m high concrete block wall with a steel doorway entrance.  This is further enclosed on 3 sides by a second perimeter wall that encloses the DLCO compound.  The storage site is situated centrally on the northern perimeter of the DLCO compound.  The former storage site appears to have been completely destroyed during the bombing, only the remains of 1 wall and a partial concrete floor slab are evident.   The surface of the site is covered in debris, rubble and the remains of the pesticide drums.  In a few places surface discoloration was observed indicating high levels of contamination remain.  There is a persistent odour of pesticide in and around the former storage area also indicating high levels of contamination.  It is likely that most of the pesticide stocks would have been stored within this central area prior to the bombing.  However, given the level of destruction material could have been spread over a large area.  At the time of the visit the remains of drums and other pesticide handling equipment were visible within and outside the compound, including in the dry riverbed around 100m from the northern perimeter.    The DLCO site is located approximately 5km south of the administrative centre of Hargeisa.  The site itself is situated at the head of the Ayaha valley on the north facing slopes.  A dry riverbed lies only a few metres to the west of the former storage area and this carries rainwater during wet periods.  The river follows the valley northwards for around 1.2km where it drains into the Malka Durduru before joining the Mariojeh river around 3 km from the site.    Around 500m north along a dirt road is the now disused Ayaha Primary School.  At around 1km north of the site this road crosses the river and continues to the outskirts of Hargeisa around 2.5km from the site.  The valley has been occupied by returning refugees from the civil war.  At the time of the visit the nearest temporary dwelling was around 500m down the valley from the site.  Following the recommendations made by KEPHIS local government and UNDP are working to relocate people living in the valley and to complete the repairs to the site perimeter wall suggested.  At the time of the visit this work was approaching completion, as was the covering of the main contaminated site with a metal-pitched roof.  However, during the visit children and grazing animals were still getting in to the DLCO compound through the uncompleted wall.       The data indicate that these pesticides have spread at least 150m and possibly as far as 900m from the area originally effected.  These pesticides, especially dieldrin and lindane, are persistent in the soil environment and can be transported  by rainwater and the wind. Additionally, during this visit, it was found that children still make their way into the contaminated site.
health_impact: No health impacts were measured; however, the following were concluded:  ï¿½Sample S1, S2 and S4 show contamination by total BHC above the Intervention Value of 2mg/kg  ï¿½Samples S1 and S4 show contamination by total drins (dieldrin, aldrin and endrin) above the Intervention Value of 4mg/kg  ï¿½All samples show contamination by BHC and drins above the Target Values of 0.01 mg/kg for total BHC and 0.005mg/kg for total drins

name: Lead pollution at Central African Batteries Manufacturers, Mashonaland West
one_sentence: This battery manufacturer has an estimated 16,000 tonnes of fine soil that is 16% lead by weight which is posing a risk to residential groundwater supplies.
description:
Central African Batteries is in Norton, a town in Mashonaland West Province of Zimbabwe. The site is at 189 Galloway Road. Norton has a population of over 20,000.   Central African Batteries is a site in the industrial area of Norton, which is low lying and flat.   The problem here stems from the pollution of the soil during battery manufacturing. The site is still active. The company has tried to recover some of the lead in the soil. However, the soil at the dumpsite still contains more than 16% lead by weight.   The local authority has not allowed Central African Batteries to dump the lead-rich soil at the dumpsites.  The contaminated soil has been left exposed on the company premises. During the rainy season, some of the lead is gradually washed into the surrounding environment.   Some of the lead is washed into the surface water river systems and some seeps into the ground. The movement of the lead from the site to the people is mainly through groundwater.  
Surrounding Central African Batteries are other industries and two residential areas, Nharira and Twinlakes, which are a kilometer or so from the site. Some of the people in these suburbs have dug shallow wells that provide the community with drinking water. Through surface and groundwater.   The site is exposed such that when there is rain some of the lead seeps into the ground and some are washed off into the environment. People who have dug shallow wells and boreholes may be affected by the lead.  During the dry season, wind exposes both children and adults to lead dust.    In addition, the workers are exposed to the lead.
health_impact: Lead has been known to affect the brain
strategy: The owner does not know how to treat the site. The lead content in the soil is too high to be dumped at the local dumpsite.
barriers: None
local_champ: Mr. J. L. Hofman Managing Director 00 263 912 274 274

name: Huepetuhe, Manu province, Madre de Dios
one_sentence: Artisanal gold extraction using mercury is contaminating the water and soil of Huepetuhe with mercury and lead.
description: The community of Huepetuhe is impacted by gold mining, which uses mercury and hydrocarbons in the extraction process. These pollutants affect soils and rivers, which serve as a source of drinking water and food for the population.  Huepetuhe is located in the Huepetuhe District, Manu province, in the Department of Madre de Dios. This village is at approximately 1400 km from Lima, but transport is only available by air and river.  The community is located in a mountainous area with many trees, with temperatures as high as 40 degrees and torrential rain. The houses are wooden with tin roofs and are seated on wooden pillars. Other huts are made of palm branches and covered with plastic, with no walls and only one room. The population only has electricity for 4 hours a day. In the area, there are 2 primary schools and one secondary school. They have a health post, but it lacks diagnostic equipment. The population of Huepetuhe lacks safe drinking water, drainage pipes, and garbage collection services.  Near the houses, in the mountains, are various mining activities, most of which are informal and artisanal. Some of these belongs to the Inversur company.   In this place, the miners are extracting gold using many chemicals, such as mercury and hydrocarbons. The waste generated from these chemicals is disposed into the environment and now is affecting the quality of soils and rivers in the area. Mining in the area produces about 20 kg of gold per day, which annually generates over 400 tons of tailings, causing damage to the population, especially in the rainy season.  Gold mining in the area is causing great harm to the ecosystem in the Amazonian jungle. Also, as the fishes and other small organisms feed on the soil and water, mercury is accumulating in their tissue, making them a danger to eat.  The population of Huepetuhe is also affected because they use the river water for drink and irrigation. Also, 40% of the population in the area works in the mines during the weekends and during periods of rain. Moreover, people in the area have reported a high incidence of diseases such as anemia and gastric problems.                    Water, soil, air, and food.  Primarily through drinking the water and using contaminated water for irrigation.
health_impact: In 1995, the Institute of Management Water and Environment, IMA, conducted a study among miners in the area of Huepetuhe and the results were startling: 78% of 45 people tested for mercury content in their blood had levels higher than the maximum limit.
strategy: In this area was conducted a pilot remediation, but so far not carried out the plan of remediation.

The cooperative produces leather goods such as sandals, handbags, key chains, and other accessories. name: Idrija, Goriska region
one_sentence: In the town of Idrija, Slovenia, the world's second largest mercury mine was active for 500 years and about 37,000 tons of mercury remains in the environment. Mercury is still drained from soil, riverbeds and floodplains and transported in the Idrijca and SoÄa Rivers to the Gulf of Trieste.  Rates of cancer are high.
description: Idrija was once home to one of the largest mercury mines in the world. After 500 years of operation, and after having produced 107,000 tons, or 13 percent of the world production of mercury, the mine has been closed due to low mercury prices and ore exhaustion.   Because of the mine's operation, this small town in the municipality of Idrija, within the GoriÅ¡ka region, has become very polluted. The mercury content in soil, water, and air is high.   In some parts of the town, the concentrations of mercury vapors in air have reached up to 120 ng/m3. In individual houses built on the remains of ore-smelting residues, radon concentrations have surpassed 1,000 Bq/m3.   Even after the shutdown of the mine, mercury concentrations in the town's air continued to be high (50 to 290 ng/m3). Mercury concentrations in some plants in the Idrija area are still very high (14.6 ng/g dry weight) despite the mine's closure. Fish from the Idrijca River also continue to show high mercury bioaccumulation. Of the twelve million tons of mercury ore that were mined, it has been estimated that more than one quarter was dissipated into the environment. Estimated "losses" (emissions to air, river and soil) are about 37,000 tons of mercury.   Today, tailings and contaminated soils in the Idrija region are eroded and serve as a continuous source of mercury pollution, especially in the nearby Gulf of Trieste.                      People are still exposed to mercury through the air, drinking water, soil, and contaminated fish.  There are two major exposure pathways for the local population. One is the exposure to atmospheric Hg in Idrija and nearby  surroundings and the other is exposure through food consumption, including fish in the coastal area of the Gulf of Trieste. Today the highest values of Hg in air are still close to the US EPA reference concentrations for chronic inhalation exposure of 0.4 ï¿½g.m-3. This indicates that some inhabitants in more exposed areas of the town of Idrija are potentially at risk due to exposure to elemental mercury through inhalation. Exposure to inorganic Hg through food consumption other than fish is not considered to pose significant problems. On the contrary, the coastal population shows increased values of Hg in hair (Ingrao et al., 1993) as an indication of exposure to MeHg due to fish consumption.
health_impact: See attached report on cancer.  Cancers, disorders of the central nervous and immune systems, and other medical problems are still more common in Idrija than elsewhere in Slovenia.  The results of a study conducted before 1990 showed a high incidence of lung cancer among the inhabitants of Idrija. More recent data also point to the increased incidence of lung cancer.  In the adult population of Idrija, most of the mercury has accumulated in the pituitary gland, thyroid gland, kidneys, and in the liver; the values for individual organs are from 3.8 to 60 times higher those found in the population of other non-contaminated areas.
notes: Under Austrian rule, Idrija was known as Idria. Mercury was discovered there in 1497, and mining productions were taken over by the government in 1580.

name: Doyaganj ULAB market, Doyagonj, Jatrabari, Dhaka
one_sentence: This is a used lead-acid battery sales and recycling market that contains about 36 battery shops.  There are residential and commercial areas in close proximity. Dust of lead due to breaking of used batteries  there is pollution of air and soil.  Lead dust can be inhaled or ingested.
description: Doyagonj is famous for different types of machines and tools factories. The area is situated in Doyagonj area of South Jatrabari, Dhaka. It is situated in a flat land and surrounded by the residential and commercial area.  This is an active used-lead acid battery sales and recycling center. They collect/buy used batteries from different parts of the city and then repair where applicable for reselling. Otherwise they break the batteries to sort out different parts for recycling. They sell the lead to smelters. This is a densely populated area and lots of people are living surrounding the battery market. There is dental clinic is on the second floor of the battery market. The people who work inside the market and live close the market are severely affected. Patients come to the dental clinic are also likely to effected by the lead and arsenic dust.  Lead and arsenic dust are polluting the air and soils of nearby areas. The main pathways are dermal contact and inhalation/ingestion.
health_impact: Workers of the battery market commonly suffer from skin diseases and acid-water burnt during acid-water drainage into the drain of the market.

name: Rostom and Moktar Used Lead-Acid Battery Recycling, Santahar, Adamdighi, Bogra
one_sentence: These are two ULAB breaking sites located within a residential area and considered  significant lead pollution sources of soil, air and water due to breaking of lead batteries and dumping of the waste. The pathways of the pollutants are mainly through dermal contact and inhalation/ingestion of lead dust.
description: Two ULAB breaking site is situated closely within the residential area along a busy road, west to Santahar bus station, Bogra District, NW Bangladesh.  The workers break used batteries to sort out different parts of the batteries. They do not smelt the lead at this site. They either supply the lead to other smelters or smelt in a different place.  This area is densely populated residential area. There are schools  and playgrounds close to this site.  Lead is the main pollutant of this area and lead dust are polluting the air,soil and water of nearby residential areas.

name: Pesticide pollution from storage in Ziguinchor  Airport
one_sentence:
The site is located inside the Ziguinchor airport. The pollution comes from a pesticide storage facility.  Contamination with the human body can be done by dermal contact with the product but also by inhalation and ingestion.  Caustic soda is irritating and corrosive to the skin, eyes, respiratory and digestive tract Soda must not be discharged to the sink: it alkalinizes the wastewater, causing the pH of the watercourses to rise and thus posing a potential threat to aquatic fauna and flora. Soda is, therefore, a danger for the property, people and the environment.

Le site est situé dans l'enceinte de l'aéroport de Ziguinchor.  La pollution vient des de la soude utilisés utilisés par les préparateurs d'hydrogène dans le cadre des activités de la météo. Cependant, cet ativité a été arrêté depuis plus de 5 ans.   Les résidus de soude caustiques sont versés dans le sol se qui favorise l'infiltration.  La contamination avec le corps humain peut se faire par contact dermique avec le produit mais aussi par inhalation et ingestion.  La soude caustique est irritante et corrosive pour la peau, les yeux, les voies respiratoire et digestive La soude ne doit pas être rejetée à l’évier : elle alcalinise les eaux usées, provoquant l’augmentation du pH des cours d’eau et représentant ainsi une menace potentielle pour la faune et la flore aquatique. La soude présente donc un danger pour les biens, l’homme et l’environnement
description: The warehouse is located in the Ziguinchor airport in southern Senegal in the Nema district.  It cohabits with the people of the neighborhood. There are vendors and a taxis garage not far from the place of contamination. Also, the school of the region is within 500 m of the site.    The chemicals are used as part of the weather works in the airport. However, the use of these products has stopped since 1998.   L’entrepôt se trouve  dans l'aéroport de Ziguinchor situé au sud du Sénégal dans le quartier Néma non loin de l'hôpital régionale.        Les produits chimiques sont utilisé Dans le cadre des travaux de la météo dans l'aéroport. Toutefois, l'utilisation de ces produits a cessé depuis 1998.
health_impact: Chemicals are generally dangerous for human and animal health but also for the environment. Some are persistent in the environment. They cause respiratory diseases, can cause cancer and can cause death or dysfunction of the body. They can be at the origin of infertility in the man like the woman. They can lead to abortions, delays in the mental development of children.  Les produits chimiques sont en générale dangereux pour la santé humaine et animale mais aussi pour l' environnement. Certains sont persistants dans l' environnement. Il sont à l' origine de maladies respiratoires, peuvent entraîner des cancers et peuvent provoquer la mort ou des dis-fonctionnement de l' organisme. Ils Peut être à l'origine d'infertilités chez l'homme comme la femme. Ils peuvent entraîner des avortements, des retards dans le développement mental des enfants.
strategy: A court terme il s'agira de délocaliser les produits en dehors de l' aéroport. Les acteurs concernés sont le gouverneur, la Direction Régionale de l'Environnement et les agents de l' éroport et de la Météo.

name: INB - Caetité - Bahia
one_sentence: Mine located 40 km from Caetité, 600 km away from Salvador, Bahia. The mine started operating in 2000 and 400 tons of yellow cake every year. It is an open cast mine. Reports from residents, from Universities, and NGOs led the Ministry of Health to conduct an epidemiologic study in the nearby city of Lagoa Real (25 km from the mine)  that showed an increase in cancer cases. The water from the wells was contaminated with U. To get the U from the rock it is used H2SO4. The liquid from the washing of the rocks leached and contaminated the water table. In 2015, the water from Lagoa Real was declared improper for consumption.
description: Mine located 40 km from Caetité, 600 km away from Salvador, Bahia. The mine started operating in 2000 and 400 tons of yellow cake every year. It is an open cast mine. There is a project to start mining underground. If that occurs, the production capacity will double.  The yellow cake is transported to Salvador in trucks, then it is sent to Europe to be concentrated (UF6). This UF6 returns to Brazil (Resende, RJ) where it is transformed in UO2 powder and pellets.  Reports from residents, from Universities, and NGOs led the Ministry of Health to conduct an epidemiologic study in the nearby city of Lagoa Real that showed an increase in cancer cases. The water from the wells was contaminated with U. To get the U from the rock it is used H2SO4. The liquid from the washing of the rocks leached and contaminated the water table. In 2015, the water from Lagoa Real was declared improper for consumption.
health_impact: Increase in cancer incidence in residents of Lagoa Nova from the contamination of the water table by the activities of the mine. See document by Oswaldo Cruz Foundation in Part 6.
notes: There is no population residing or working within 500 m. The nearest city to the north is located 12 km away. Lagoa Real is located 25 km away BUT the water has been contaminated.
strategy: - interdiction of the contaminated points;  - drinking waters distribution for the population.
remediation_plan: - quarterly evaluation of the quality of the water;  - area under inquiry.
barriers: Slowness in the solution of the problem.

name: ULAB Sales & Servicing Shops, Ponchoboti, Fatullah, Narayanganj
one_sentence: There are several ULAB sales and servicing/recycling shops in the area. Lead dust due to the breaking of batteries pollutes  soil and water bodies of residential areas around the shops. Shop Workers and people living in the area are exposed to lead toxicity through dermal contact and inhalation/ ingestion of lead dust.
description: Ponchoboti is located in Fatullah union of Narayanganj Sadar upazila under Narayanganj district, Dhaka division. Ponchboti is known for various small and cottage industries. It is situated south of Dhaka city on a flat alluvial land by the eastern side of river Buriganga. There are several used-lead acid battery sales and servicing/recycling shops in Ponchoboti area. They collect/buy used batteries to repair/ service where possible for reselling. They also break the batteries that are not repairable for selling the lead plates to smelters.    This is a densely populated residential and commercial area. The people who work inside the shops and live close the shops are severely affected by lead and arsenic dust.   Lead and arsenic dust are polluting the air, soils and water bodies of nearby areas. The main pathways are dermal contact and inhalation/ ingestion.

name: Fatema  Lead Smelting Factory, Goalbari, Shimulia, Savar, Dhaka
one_sentence: A lead smelting site in the rural area and a source of lead and arsenic pollution in air, soil and water bodies. Probable pathways of toxic pollutants are dermal contact and inhalation/ ingestion.
description: This is rather a well structured lead smelting factory situated along Bashkhali canal at Goalbari village of Shimulia union, north of Savar upazila, Dhaka.   They usually collect slag from Rahim Afrooz battery manufacturing industry for recycling. They crush the collected slag to separate out the un-melted/partially melted metal lead granules for re-smelting. It has a treatment plant for smoke from the furnace.  This area is a moderately  populated residential and agricultural flat land.   Lead and arsenic are the main pollutant for air,soil and water bodies of the area. The workers of the factory and people living in the area are exposed to toxicity through dermal contact and inhalation/ingestion of toxic pollutants.

name: Walajapet Pond Water Polluted Site, Vellore, Tamilnadu
one_sentence: Leather tanneries and other industries such as metal plating, paint manufacture, and fertilizer manufacture, located near the Palar River, have been polluting the Walajapet Pond with Chromium and other heavy metals. About 20,000 people use the Walajapet Pond as a potable water source.
description: The site is a polluted pond in western side of Walajapet town just near the NH $. Walajapet is a town in Tamilnadu. It is strategically located on the Palar River on the route between Chennai (Madras) and Bangalore. By bus, this locality can be reached in about 30 minutes from Vellore city center and in about 2.5 hours from Chennai. It is well connected both by road and railways. Walajah Road railway station is located about 4.5 km from the town, lying between Arakkonam and Katpadi junctions on the important railway route connecting Chennai to Coimbatore and Bangalore.It was the station connecting Arakonam and Katpadi, the first rail route in tamilnadu.  This town, located in the Vellore District, is considered to be the First Municipality and Taluk of Tamil Nadu, believed to have been formed in 1866. Former President and prominent Indian philosopher Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan (1888 - 1975) and noted Tamil scholar Mu. Varadarasanar affectionately called "Mu. Va" were among those studied in the Government Higher Secondary School of Walajapet that celebrated its centenary a decade ago. â€¢	Neighbouring localities (Vellore city) : Arcot, Melvisharam, Ranipet, Vellore, Thiruvalam â€¢	Neighbouring Towns : Arani, Arakkonam, Cheyyar, Kanchipuram, Kaveripakkam, Sholingur As of 2001 India census[1], Walajapet had a population of 29,472. Males constitute 50% of the population and females 50%. Walajapet has an average literacy rate of 74.51%, higher than the national average of 59.5%: male literacy is 80.58%, and female literacy is 68.44%. In Walajapet, 10.86% of the population is under 6 years of age.
health_impact: Mrs Alirani Mohan of Walajapet Govt. Hospital o said that everyday around 15 workers of different tanneries come for their treatment. The ratio of male & female workers is 90:10.Most of the workers suffer due to TB, skin rashes, breathing trouble. Most of the  women patients come to the hospital residing in and around polluted sites of Ranipet & Walajapet suffer due to uterus cancer, tumer. After consultation said cases are referred to Kanchipuram Cancer Hospital & TB Hospital in Chennai.  Every year 15-20 cases of tumer and 20-30 cases of uterus cancer are referred to the said hospital for their treatment.  Tumers form in different parts of the body like abdomen, cervical and head.  The cases of ulcer are referred to Vellore Government hospital.   Mrs Sguna Selvi of Vannivedu told us that the most of the villagers residing the ponds are suffering from throat infection and iching poblem

name: Binagadi Steel Production Company
one_sentence: Binagadi Steel Company is the main steel production plant in the South Caucasus. It is very important to note that all the technology that is used in the plant is outdated. Carbon Monixide and Sulfur Dioxide are the main contaminants of this pollution source and are exposing people via the inhalation/ingestion route. The location of this site is also heavily polluted by other sources.
description: Baku Steel Company is located in the Binagadi District of Baku Administrative region, in the north part of Baku city. The factory was constructed in 1969 as the main steel production plant in the South Caucasus. It was an important producer for the oil machinery industry in Azerbaijan, which was the main oil machinery producer in the former Soviet Union. The technology used in the plant is outdated in old. Some of machinery was imported from Germany in the end 19th century and is still used. These machines were brought here from other plants.  It is still the main producer of the steel in Azerbaijan.   Carbon monoxide and sulfur dioxide are the main contaminants from this source. Carbon monoxide is a toxic gas without color, taste and odor. It inhibits the blood's ability to carry oxygen to vital organs such as the heart and brain. Short term exposure in low concentration for 2-3 hours may cause slight headache, tiredness, fatigue, nausea and dizziness. High concentrations (e.g. 1600 ppm) for 1 hour can cause death. There is little information regarding long-term exposure in low concentrations. According to local doctors, such exposures may cause blood and lung cancer. Azerbaijan State Statistical Committee informs that over the past 10 years, the number of local people ill with lung cancer increased nearly two times. We have official information of the ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources about the level of carbon monoxide.  When close to the site, one notices the smell of rotten eggs, an indicator of SO2. The area where the site is located is also heavily polluted by other sources. Because the climate is dry, long-term droughts easily cause dust that is mixed with SO2, which may cause respiratory diseases. SO2 is poisonous and irritates the respiratory system of humans. Investigators  assumed that rains after long droughts may easily cause acid rains which may contain H2SO4. That is why investigators took soil samples from the area.  Baku is a city, where North winds dominate. Because this site is located in North of Baku, the contaminants are easily blown south and diffuse through the atmosphere of the city.  The area is believed to be contaminated by a number of other sources and may be dangerous for human habitation.     In order to measure pollution, investigators took an air sample, mixed it with water and measured the resulting pH level that was 4,2. This is an indicator of air pollution.   On August 25, 2012, investigators attended a meeting with the Ministry of Environment, where an official of the ministry talked about health impacts of this site. He talked about different options that may be implemented. Recently there is strong recognition from the Government that the site should be closed.
health_impact: The toxic effects of carbon monoxide and sulfur dioxide are well studied. Respiratory and skin diseases in this area are rather common. There were no studies showing a direct impact of this plant on local health. However, many in government and civil society assume such an impact.
strategy: New technologies to minimise the pollution can be implemented, or the factory must be closed.  BI may assist the goverment to bring new air protection technologies. Trees may be planted around the factory.
remediation_plan: 10-12 month are rather enough to complete cleanup.
barriers: There are many pollution sources arounf this site, that may reduce effects of cleanup.

name: Tangra, Kolkata
one_sentence: Despite a Supreme Court order mandating that tannery units relocate, several remain illegally in operation in Tangra, and are contaminating the groundwater with hexavalent chromium. Residents may be exposed through the drinking water and fish consumption.
description:
Tangra, lying on the outskirts of Calcutta, was famous for its leather tanning industry (523 units). In 2001 and 2002, in response to a public interest litigation lawsuit alleging that pollution from the industries exceeded the State pollution standards, the Supreme Court order forced the tanneries to relocate to a self-contained leather-processing complex in the Bantala area. However some tanneries are still in Tangra despite relocation orders. "The West Bengal Government is planning to declare the Bantala Leather Complex as a notified area. A notified area is any land area which has been earmarked by legal provisions. The reasons given for doing this by the Chief Ministerâ€™s Secretariat is that doing so will enable an authority to look after its infrastructure and impose taxes on units operating there. The 1,300-acre Calcutta Leather Complex, around 14km from Science City, is presently administered by a state-appointed panel. The state government wants to set up a notified authority for the complex that will have statutory powers to collect taxes and other user charges and can administer the area in a smooth and orderly manner," said an official of the industries department. Urban development minister Asok Bhattacharyya said: "I have heard about the proposal... but things haven't moved much. If the conversion happens, we will have to empower the body with powers of raising revenue. For that, legislative sanction will be necessary." The state had joined hands with a private firm, ML Dalmia & Company, to set up the leather complex in the mid-1990s after the Supreme Court had ordered tanneries out of the city. The tanneries started shifting from 2004. But with complaints of mismanagement pouring in, the state decided to hand over the administration of the complex to a new authority by declaring it a notified area. The functioning of the state panel, which doesn't have resources to spend on infrastructure, has drawn criticism from various stakeholders, including the tannery owners and the developers of the Rs 1,500-crore project. The former tanneries had added their quota of filth to a city notorious for dirt and decay. The groundwater is suspected to be contaminated with hexavalent chromium from the tanneries. People may be exposed to the contaminant through fish and tubewells. Open gutters have a typical blue chromate color which is commonly utilized as a tanning agent. It is to be noted that Ward no 58 (Tangra, Tiljala)is the largest ward in Kolkata and it also happens to be the ward in which 99.98% of population are slum dwellers making them more vulnerable to the impacts of pollution. Again, according to a 1995 report of the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, presence of chrome-based tanning among Kolkata tanners, with inappropriate wastewater drainage and collection systems, was causing serious environmental, health and hygiene problems. The report indicated that the highly congested habitations offered little or no scope for future expansion, modernisation or installation of effluent treatment plants. Police, along with officials of the civic body, state pollution control board and CESC sealed 11 illegal tanneries in Tiljala, Topsia, Tangra and Karaya in December 2008. This news indicates that illegal taneries are still operating in Tangra. The crackdown will continue until all the illegal tanneries have been sealed, said Ajey Ranade, the superintendent of South 24-Parganas police.

Coordinates: Lat=22.5545340001, Lon=88.3840440001 The groundwater is suspected to be contaminated with hexavalent chromium from the tanneries. People may be exposed to the contaminant by consuming fish in which it may have bio-accumulated.
health_impact: No visible health effects could be observed during our visit.  Common health impacts from this type of pollution include: Ulcers Skin diseases Rheumatic fever Jaundice Dizziness, headaches, weakness Abdominal pain Eye problems
strategy: Analysis of drinking water and groundwater should be conducted to determine if there is any significant threat to human health. As part of the relocation process the tanneries were required to deposit funds with the Ministry of Environment and Forests to pay for any legacy contamination remediation. These funds could be utilized for testing purposes.
barriers: The Chinese community is not pleased with the required move of tanneries, and would not be interested in any activities that would compromise their land claims and restaurant development plans. There is a Chinese cemetery in the neighborhood also.

name: Hai Bei Chemical Factory, Hai Yan county, Qing Hai province
one_sentence: Waste products from a closed Hai Bei Chemical factory have contaminated the groundwater and soil of Hai Yan county with hexavalent chromium.
description: Hai Yan county is located in Qinghai Province, and it is the headstream of Huangshui. To the north of Hai Yan county are Qilian and Menyuan, to the the east are Datong and Huangzhong, to the south are Huangzhong and Gonghe, and to the west is Gangcha.    The total population of Hai Yan county is 24,400. Ethnic minorities (Tibetan, Mongolian, Hui, Tu and others) accounts for 43.4% of the total population. 77.7% of the population (18,800) is engaged in agricultural labor of animal husbandry. The total area of Hai Yan county is 4580.07 square kilometers; this accounts for 0.62% of the total area of Qinghai Province.  The main economic production activity in Hai Yan county is stockbreeding. The total grassland area of Hai Yan county is about 1394 square kilometers, and the pasture area in the summer and autumn months is 1021 square kilometers, of which livestock pastures account for 65,000 square meters.  Hai Yan county has 26 administrative villages, and 49 agricultural production cooperatives. Each contains roughly four villages engaged in animal husbandry, one in agriculture, and two towns.  The county is located in the southeast of the province, the center of political, economic, and cultural activities. Means of transportation throughout the county is very convenient, and contains the main components of the southern " Silk Road." In 1993, Hai Bei chemical company moved to Hai Yan county, and now provides a multitude of industrial facilities to advance the economic development of Hai Yan county.  The Haibei Chemical Factory discharged a large amount of waste residue and waste water, which contained high concentrations of hexavalent chromium.  This pollutant has contaminated the groundwater and surrounding grasslands. Spring and well water sources in the villages near the facility have become yellow. Fish in these sources have died, and the polluted water is being used for irrigation; subsequently, food production has decreased. Livestock have been affected, and residents are suffering from dry mouths and epistaxis after drinking the water.  See URL link to engineering report PDF (abstract in English, report in Chinese) on page 6.             The Haibei chemical factory discharged a large amount of waste, which contained high concentrations of hexavalent chromium, into the water sources of the county. The soil is also contaminated.
health_impact: Humans and animals in the surrounding villages have been poisoned, the production of crops has been reduced, and regional vegetation has been severely damaged.  There have been reports of people suffering from dry mouth/nose, and even epistaxis (nosebleed), after drinking the polluted water.
notes: See URL link to engineering report PDF (abstract in English, report in Chinese) on page 6.
strategy: See URL link to engineering report PDF (abstract in English, report in Chinese) on page 6.  1. cultivation of plants  2. changes in irrigation water  time frame: 3 years
remediation_plan: 1. close drinking water wells around key polluted sites 2. clean-up solid waste of the factory 3. transport solid waste to appropriative residue area  time frame: 1 year

name: Paulínia/SP
one_sentence: The operations of a number of companies have potentially contributed to the contamination in the city Paulínia-SP. People have been exposed to chemicals, such as POPs and pesticides, through contaminated air, dust, soil, and food.
description: Update - 2016:  The contaminated area is located approximately 10 km from the entrance portal of Paulínia, in the state of São Paulo. The area is bordered by the river Atibaia (north, south and west). The southeast is a straight line. Between the industry and the river there´s an área of about 100m that forms a strip along the river. This strip was a residential area called Recanto dos Pássaros. It was composed of small farms. When the contamination was confirmed, residents of 66 houses had to leave due to soil contamination. Of these houses, 64 were demolished. The area comprises several other industries. The site is still to be remediated.
health_impact: Among the workers: 1) - Examination of thyroid abnormalities was 41 workers (20% of the examined) 2) - Tests carried out showed that 25% of the individuals had some type of problem of the laboratory or functional and could be linked to activity working at Shell, 3) - Dr. Reinaldo Farina former doctor from Shell refers to 177 cases of sub-clinical poisoning.  Residents: 1) - were contaminated by: Aldrin, endrin, endosulfan, DDT, zinc, arsenic, copper and aluminum, lead. (see maps in Part 06); 2) - 55% of the population of residents assessed had confirmed the framework of chronic poisoning due to exposure to organochlorines and heavy metals, 63% took part had some type of chronic poisoning by chlorine and / or heavy metals, 24% with a framework suggestive chronic intoxication be examined; 3) - organochlorine compound was detected in adipose tissue in a range from 0.001 to 0.03 mg / kg. The following proportions: HCB (0.001 mg/kg), alpha-HCH (0.008 mg/kg), beta-HCH (0.007 mg/kg), gamma-HCH (0.027 mg/kg), delta-HCH (0.005 mg/kg ), heptachlor (0.0056 mg/kg), heptachlor epoxide (0.006 mg/kg), aldrin (0.007 mg/kg), OP-DDE (0.01 mg/kg), PP-DDE (0.01 mg/kg), endosulfan-alpha (0.007 mg/kg), endosulfan-Beta (0.03 mg/kg), dieldrin (0.01 mg/kg), endrin (0.01 mg/kg), OP-DDD (0.01 mg/kg), PP-DDD (0.01 mg/kg), OP-DDT (0.01 mg/kg), PP-DDT (0.001 mg/kg).
notes: Update - 2016: A report done by the Municipal Secretary of Health shows that old residents present levels of pesticides in their blood and adipose tissue above the brazilian standards.  Blood: Endrin: 3.42 micrograms per liter, ppDDT 0.3 micrograms per liter (standard 0.01-0.07), ppDDD 8.4 micrograms per liter. Adipose tissue: lindane 1.3 g per kg  (Epidemiological Study Secretary of Health 2003 - Please refer to this document for more information and the standards in Part 5) ________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________  Previous information:  Workers (and residents who agreed) are currently participating in an evaluation by the secretary of health. This assessment is based on a protocol to monitor the health of people exposed permanently. Some employees had testing for dioxins and furans in adipose tissue and the result was positive.
strategy: Part of the contaminated soil was removed and sent for incineration. Animals used for food were killed, the farms were being abandoned and the buildings demolished.
remediation_plan: Between 1998 and 2000, the company installed a stripping tower with air injection to treat the contaminated aquifer, but the process dragged contaminants into the atmosphere. This project has been criticized and then from 2004 was installed with other filtration system process. However, there is no information available about how the new system. There is no transparency in informing the public. There is no certainty about the efficiency of the system.
barriers: The lack of transparency and facilitation for participation of the public concerned may be the biggest obstacle to the success of remediation. For example in a recent public hearing in the Legislative Assembly of the State of Sao Paulo Shell reported that the remediation will be fully completed in 2010. The CSD-GEOCLOCK Company contracted to carry out the work reports that will be in 2014. However, ex-workers report that due to the high degree these dates may not be correct.

name: Canabrava (Barradão) - Salvador - Ba
one_sentence: Canabrava is a peripheral district of Salvador in Bahia, which is located in the area of the old city dump that operated during the period 1974 to 1994. The neighborhood has undergone a process of urbanization, where today we can find houses, buildings, schools, churches, shops and supermarkets. However the results of the XRF showed a high incidence of Zirconium with values above the limit, we can suspect that the population and the visitors can be contaminated by exposure to Zirconium by the inhaled and endemic routes.  The selective collection system of the City Hall of Salvador is carried out through LIMPURB and all solid waste (including debris) was deposited where today the Manuel Barradas stadium (Barradão) is located, in which, today its removal helped in the development of the surrounding region of the stadium, which no longer had to live with the emission of gaseous pollutants and consequent bad smell. When the assessment was performed we found high levels of Zirconium. It is know that it causes eye and skin irritation and, if inhaled, can lead to lung granuloma. name: Informal Used Lead Acid Battery Recycling Plant in Sitio Tingga-an, Barangay San Nicolas, Cebu City
one_sentence: The operations of an informal used lead acid battery recycling plant in Tingga-an are contaminating local soils with high levels of lead, arsenic, and cadmium.
description: Cebu City, the capital city of Cebu, is considered the second most significant metropolitan center in the Philippines. The city is located on the eastern shore of Cebu. Cebu is the Philippines' main domestic shipping port and is home to about 80 % of the country's domestic shipping companies and is a significant center of commerce, trade and industry in the Visayas and Mindanao regions. It has a population of about 2,439,005 people based on the 2007 Philippine Population census.  Cebu City has 81 barangays with a total population of 798,809 people (2007 census). Its trade and industry are based mainly on small and medium scale business enterprises and among these are Cebu Business Park and IT industries created by the Ayalas. In addition, export industries producing products such as semiconductors, electronic watches, electrical equipment, cameras and furniture are also booming in the region.  Another potential industry that may add to the economy of Cebu is the legal/formal recycling of IT materials and metals like ULAB. However, these types of industries are not yet common in the region.   For the entirety of the Visayas and Mindanao regions, there is only one registered ULAB facility, which is situated in Mandaue City. The high demand of recycling lead from ULAB has created an informal sector of ULAB recycling. Informal ULAB recycling poses hazards not only to the recyclers, but also to the community due to environmental contamination with heavy metals.  An informal ULAB recycling site was located in Sitio Tingga-an, Barangay San Nicolas, Cebu City. Barangay San Nicolas hosts 5,407 people based on 2007 Philippine Population Census, and of this, around 2000 people are possibly affected by lead and other heavy metals. According to the barangay health officer and some residents of Sitio Tingga-an, recycling is done usually within the community, by the roadside and outside of homes.   During our site visit we were able to witness the recycling done by the side of the road. Acids were directly dumped into sewers/canals and road cement. The recycling site is adjacent to a rice store/granary and opposite a school. Kids were playing in the vicinity, and many residents were eating here as well. Refreshments and other food vendors sell their products in this contaminated site.  The facility is a cottage industry in a shanty town that has operated for about 30 years, with about 40-60 families doing informal recycling over a 1 hectare area. Before that, a poultry operation was at the site. A school is across the street (about 75 meters away) with 200 elementary and 100 high school students.  There was a small old lead smelter along the street in front of the shanty town, behind a fence and a rice mill and warehouse is situated next door.  The lead is melted into pellets for buyers and used for galvanized iron sheet fasteners and to seal nail heads when nailing concrete.   According to the Barangay health officer, a health assessment was conducted by the University of the Philippines Manila about three to four years ago. Five children of those directly involved in the informal ULAB recycling and who were residing in the area for a long time were selected as respondents. Lead levels in their blood were examined and results showed that all of the respondents had blood lead levels exceeding health standards.  The DENR-EMB Region 7 and the Local Government Unit have already prohibited this economic activity. They have formed an enforcement team, but people continue ULAB recycling, as it is their source of income. There is more than one pathway. One is through the soil, as children may inhale lead dust while playing. Food contamination is also possible since sidewalk food vendors are in the vicinity. Rice stores/granaries are also present nearby thus displays of rice could be contaminated with lead dust.  Water could also be a pathway since some of the pipes for drinking water in the area are situated along these polluted canals.
health_impact: According to the Barangay health officer, a health assessment was conducted by the University of the Philippines Manila about three to four years ago. Five children of those directly involved in the informal ULAB recycling and who are residing in the area for a long time were selected as respondents. Lead levels in their blood were examined and results showed that all of the respondents had blood lead levels exceeding health standards.  Informal ULAB recyclers face hazards too, since they are not given personal protective gears.   The soil sample concentrations of arsenic, mercury, copper, and cadmium were compared to the United States' Centers for Disease Control minimum risk level (MRL) standards for toxic exposure. Using international standard values for the amount of soil an average weight 5 year old child ingests, calculations showed that all four metals exceeded MRL values for oral consumption of 100mg of soil for an 18.5 kg child per day. Mercury concentration just barely exceeded the MRL standard, copper had exceeded the MRL value by 3.7 times, and cadmium soil concentrations exceeded the MRL values by more than 33 times.  However, the most alarming value is of arsenic concentration, which exceeded the MRL value for chronic exposure by more than 668 times.  There are a number of limitations in these calculations, done retrospectively with the limited data available.  Primarily, this only accounts for the oral ingestion route of inadvertent soil intake by children, and no other exposure pathway (such as inhalation of fine particles.) Additionally, the average weight of children in the Philippines is likely lower than the given WHO standard.  Also, children living in this community likely eat more than just 100mg of dirt, the worldwide average value used in the calculations.  Therefore, it is likely that with sufficient data, computations would show that exposure in children is even greater than the values calculated here.  -U.S. CDC's Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry. http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/mrls/index.asp
notes: - had initial plan to remediate this area with excavation of soils and replacement with 1 foot of clean soil mixed with limestone.  No timeline or details.
strategy: 1.) Conduct a more detailed assessment in the area.  2.) Community Education  using various approaches and media. IEC awareness through various schools and media networks. And occupational hazard and PPE promotion among owners/operators and workers in the ULAB salvage yards.  3.) Meeting with ULAB recyclers to discuss data gathered by Blacksmith Institute and initial remediation plan.  4.) Meeting with stakeholders to discuss remediation plan and contribution to the remediation of each partner organization.  5.) Actual remediation - removal of  contaminated soil.     Disposal of contaminated soil in a hazardous waste treatment facility.     Use of binding reagents such as boimin and other tested stabilizing reagents.     Repalce with good soil.  6.) Conduct training or seminar for ULAB owners and workers regarding proper handling of hazardous waste that are common in their workplace.  7.) Monitoring of soil lead levels after remediation.     Monitoring of air quality in the area.  8.) Blood sampling of ULAB workers before and after remediation.   Key Players: Blacksmith Institute, LGU, DENR

It has an average elevation of 316 metres (1036 feet), and is extremely hot and dry during summer when temperature soars to as high as 43 degree C (110 F). The winter is cold and dry with dipping temperatures. Ambur is well connected by road, on the Chennai- Bangalore National Expressway, and by rail on the Chennai-Jolarpettai line with a number of express/superfast trains to Chennai, Bangalore, Coimbatore, Mysore, Erode, etc.  Factories in Ambur manufacture shoes for the world's leading footwear brand names like Floursheim, Lumberjack, Gabor, primigi, caterpillar, Clarks, Fretzmen, Coll Hann, Hi-Line, Hugo Boss, Marc, and many more. Hence, it is also known as a "Leather City," and temperatures reach up to 10 degree C during the night. One of the problems that Ambur faces is polluted ground water, which is not potable. This happened due to the chemicals released by the leather tanneries directly into the most-of-the-time-dry Palar River traversing across Ambur before the Common Effluent Treatment Plants that use Reverse Osmosis process were installed. However, with strict measures taken by the State Government, most of the companies have now installed effluent treatment plants to treat the water from harsh chemicals such as hexavalent chromium, trivalent chromium, etc.    People from the area are exposed to the above contaminants through the consumption of food,vegetables,drinking water, and milk.

name: Jua Kali Informal Fabricating and Spray Painting Area, Gikomba, Nairobi
one_sentence: Informal fabricators in Jua Kali use chromium, lead, mercury and cadmium-contaminated paints (See attached KEPHIS laboratory report in Part 6) to spray vehicles, fridges, metallic boxes etc. in the densely populated Gikomba area.   The workers do not wear safety gear while working. The sprayed paint is spread in wind and air across the surrounding environs and finally deposited on surrounding soils and buildings causing metal contamination.  Local communities can inhale the metal-contaminated air and prayed paint, ingest metal-contaminated soils, dust and food. Workers are mainly exposed to the toxic metals through inhalation of sprayed paint/contaminated air, ingestion of contaminated dust and skin contact with the paint while working.
description: Jua Kali is located in Nairobi’s largest market, Gikomba along latitude: -1.2916969 and longitude: 36.8426885, about 4km from Nairobi’s Central Business District. The area is generally flat and very windy. The area borders Shauri Moyo slums and Railways residential estates. Several foot paths cross the area. The local communities use piped water for drinking, industrial and domestic purposes. The area is characterized by several schools, hospitals, food kiosk and business centers.   Over 2000 (two thousand) informal fabricators in Jua Kali use chromium, lead, cadmium and mercury-contaminated paints (See attached laboratory report in Part 6) to spray vehicles, fridges, metallic boxes etc. in the densely populated Gikomba area. The workers lack safety and environmental controls while working. The sprayed paint is transported via wind and air across the surrounding environs and finally deposited on surrounding markets, soils and buildings causing widespread metal contamination. Wastes from the activities are deposited in open dumps on site. Local communities can inhale the metal-contaminated air, ingest metal-contaminated soils, dust and food. Workers are mainly exposed through direct inhalation of sprayed paint, ingestion of contaminated dust and constant direct skin contact with the paint while working. School children live and school in nearby residences and schools and are possibly exposed.
health_impact: Respiratory problems were reported by most workers.
notes: None
strategy: - Creation of awareness on pollution from improper use of leaded paint and artisanal trainings. -Provision of protective gears to workers/spray painters. -Advise workers and paint manufacturers to change to environmentally friendly technology and safe paints. -Advise relevant authorities on the need for stringent measures; policy and regulations to minimize exposures and/or eliminate leaded paint.
remediation_plan: Trainings Remediation of contaminated site Change of paint manufacturing technology Proper regulations and standards for lead in paint and use. Any other
barriers: None

name: Budi River, Duhabi-9 VDC, Sunsari
one_sentence: Asian Leather Industry Pvt Ltd and United Tanneries are dumping untreated waste water into the Budi River. They are also dumping significant amounts of chromium-mixed solid waste into the banks of the river and nearby communities.
description: Duhabi-9 is located in Sunsari District in the eastern region of Nepal. As It is located in the Terai region, the land is mostly flat. The general climate is very hot and dry. The major river system flowing through the area is the Budi River, which divides Morang and Sunsari districts and subsequently flows across the boarder to India.  Two tanning industries, namely, Asian Leather Industry Pvt Ltd and United Tanneries are directly discharging untreated waste water into the river. Furthermore, they are also dumping a large amount of chromium-mixed solid waste (skin, hides and fats) in the banks of the river and in the nearby communities.  These industries have been in operation since 1988.                           * Suface Water - Dermal * Groudwater - Oral * Soil - Dermal * Air - Inhalation/ Dermal
health_impact: * Respiratory Problem * Skin related diseases * nasal septum perforation * dermatitis * gangrene etc  1 ) According to local medical shop owner(Mr. Bhuwaneshwor Yadav) maximum number of patients are reported to have eyes, skin and resiratory related problems. During an interview, Mr. Sanjay Sharma and Manoj Sharma, locals living next to the industrial area, also informed on the similar health problems faced by the local people.  They also informed that the livestock animals get immediately killed after getting bitten by the dogs. These dogs come to the area to eat the industrial waste (skins, hides, fats).    2) Mr Ram charitra Sah, staff scientist, had visited the industries in 2003. He reported that he had skin irritation for six months.
notes: Likely Transmission path continued...   Budi river receives a huge amount of untreted industrial waste from the Tanning Industries.  People use the river water for several purposes: irrigation, swimming (mostly children), bathing, washing dishes and clothes. There is a high risk of this hazardous waste water getting mixed up with the ground water, which is drawn out by the locals using tube wells and dug wells for drinking. The overall area consists of agricultural fields, residential areas and major pathways. Most people working in the fields do not use any safety measures and come directly into contact with the soil. People, mostly children, walk barefoot.  Hazardous wastes dumped outside the industry area produce very strong and foul odor.
strategy: * Increase awareness on pollution problem and health impacts among all stakeholders.   * Construction of a Chromium treatment plant.  * Proper dumping site development.  Key players: Local Municipal authorities, Community Dwellers, Industry owner and workers  Time frame - This can be done over a period of six months to 1 year.
remediation_plan: * Setting up an industrial zone with adequate treatment facilities  * Relocation of the industries from residential areas to such industrail zones, as per the governmen't plan.
barriers: * Lack of awareness among the stakeholders on the glaring pollution problem and its severe health impacts   * Lack of social initiatives  * Lack of commitment from the concerned goverment agencies  * Deficiency of infrastructures and expertise  * Financial constraints

name: Beilin village, Guiyu town, Shantou City, Guangdong province
one_sentence: Beilin Village is an e-waste recycling village that suffers from Chromium and lead pollution in water and sediments as a result of make-shift recycling enterprises.
description: Beilin Village is an e-waste recycling village that suffers from Chromium and lead pollution in water and sediments as a result of make-shift recycling enterprises. It is within the South Asian tropics climatic region.  The annual mean temperature is 21.4 degrees Celsius and the yearly average precipitation is 13,864 millimeters.      Guiyu Town is an electronic trash recycling city. Every day more than 100 freight vehicles filled with e-waste dump their loads in the town. Beilin village is not far away from Guiyu Town's center, it is located at the northwest of the town.  People resort to all means to obtain the used metal within the e-waste. The primary method is to burn down the worn out electric wire and cable with the sulfur acid water flushing the circuit wafer and burning trash piled up along the river.       In Beilin village, there is a constant haze of black smoke and there are shiny black ponds that emit a foul odor. Here, air was suffocated, river water was polluted, soil was poisoned. The serious contaminated ecological environment has also impaired villagers' health. Many labors were infected the respiratory disease, the skin presented ulcer, even had cancer.  Water, soil, food, air   e-waste is burned and then washed over with water, polluting both the air and the water (and the soil).  The water and soi, in turn, contaminate the food.

name: Lead pollution at Ngasa-2 oil exploration well, Angara spit, Kaiso Village, Bugashya County, Hoima District
one_sentence: The oil exploration site is located in Kaiso Village close to a fishing lagoon. The heavy metal contamination originates from the drilling operations and is dispersed on the ground in the adjacent area.
description: The site is located in Kaiso Village, Kabale Parish, Bugashya Subcounty, Bugashya County in Hoima District. Ngasa-2 lies on the low-lying Kaiso-Tonya flats on a spit of land  at the shores of Lake Albert closing to is a fishing Angara lagoon. The area is also located a few distance from the fishing village. The spectacular nature of the site attracts many tourist who enjoy fishing and the surrounding community are predominantly fishermen with limited animals. The contaminant originate from drilling cutting which are dispersed on the ground in the adjacent area.  The drilling operations are not known for using heavy metals for therefore the heavy metals present could be attributed to the addition during drilling. Two Possible sources arise: Heavy metal brought to the surface from the earth's crust or the chemicals added makes the metals available from their fixed state.  The dominant transmission path is through drinking water from community wells near the site and through direct contact from water in the lagoon used for bathing. Animals too drink the same water from the lagoon thus through the food chain. The dominant transmission path is through drinking water from community wells near the site and through direct contact from water in the lagoon used for bathing. Animals too drink the same water from the lagoon thus through the food chain.
health_impact: Generally the operations are recent event and given the time span limited evident on the health impacts of the heavy metals can be adduced at this stage. However considering the the pollutant is dispersed in the waters sources that are important to the community livelihood this incessant exposure of the community to the pollutant is likely to induce various health effects associated with these heavy metals.
notes: However, in the assessment area, there is no link of the contaminant with the health of the community. This is because they are no illness that produce symptoms related to the heavy metals because the pollution is recent event.
strategy: Chemical stabilization, to reduce the solubility of heavy metals by adding nono -toxic materials to the soil - Removal of polluted surface soil, and replacing it with clean soil; - Covering the polluted site with clean soil - On- site chemical leaching, using some acid agent - dilution method, mixing polluted soil with clean soil to dilute the concentration of heavy metals -Remediation by plants, using for example suitable plant tree species.
remediation_plan: Chemical stabilzation seems to be the most cost- effective remediation technique for contaminated sites, then followed by bioremediation using appropriate tree species.
barriers: There is a high contraversy between the Regulators and the Parties responsible for contaminating this area on how to remedaite. Therefore any move in the positive direction can not be resisted and is highly welcome.

name: Madre de Deus/BA
one_sentence: In the municipality of Madre de Dios, in Bahia is  an area that has suffered great environmental impacts due to the industrial activities that occur in this region. The presence of Lead and Manganese in the soil was indicated through the measurements. The population is exposed by inhalation, dermal and ingestion from dust in soil and air.
description: Madre de Deus is the smallest municipality in the state, composed of three islands: Mother of God, Maria Guarda and das Vacas. It is located in Recôncavo Baiano, in the northern portion of Todos os Santos Bay - BTS, is part of the Metropolitan Region of Salvador - RMS and the Environmental Protection Area All Saints - APA-BTS, has Candeias and São Francisco do Conde as municipalities. It has a total area of 11.14 km², 17.376 inhabitants and a density of 1,559 hab / km² (IBGE, 2010). The industrial activities of the region include operations of storage, loading and unloading of vessels and tank trucks; supply of fuel for ships; transfer of oil and by-products through pipelines; storage of petroleum derivatives and receipt of derivatives from the Landulfo Alves Refinery - RLAM. It still has an asphalt factory on the banks of a mangrove area, which represent the threats present in the municipality. The presence of Lead and Manganese in the soil was indicated through the measurements. The population is exposed by inhalation, dermal and ingestion from dust in soil and air.
health_impact: No health study was done.
