name: Demolished DDT Factory Site, Amangarh, Nowshera, North West Frontier Province (NWFP)
one_sentence: The DDT factory was established in 1963 to meet the country's pesticide needs. In 1994, the factory closed due to a ban on pesticides. DDT can still be smelled in the air by residents living near the abandoned factory.
description: The area surrounding Amman Gharh, Nowshera, North West Frontier Province (NWFP), has been found to have high levels of DDT contamination from an abandoned DDT production facility.   Nowshera one of the largest cities of NWFP lies on the Grand Trunk Road 27 miles due east of Peshawar. It is located along the banks of River Kabul. It is also at the junction of Peshawar and Swat Road. Total area of the Nowshera District is 1748 square kilometers.  According to a 1998 report, the district has a population of 874,000 (urban population = 26%). Children under 15 years of age constitute 45% of the total population. There are numerous streams in the area  which are the only source of drinking water for many villages.  The historical city of Nowshera is located at a distance of 120km from Islamabad international airport and 48 km from Peshawar International airport.   The rivers in the District are the Kabul and Indus River. The Kabul River enters the village at its Western side and runs through plain and joins Indus River at Kund near Khairabad.  Climate is temperate. One can enjoy cold in winters and hot in summers. Summers are hot and humid with temperature range of 35-40 Â°C. Winters are cold with varying temperature of 5 Â°C to -1 Â°C. But spring and autumn are pleasant and refreshing. The predominant wind direction is North East to South West.  There are big industries there, such as Paper International Ltd (previously known as Adam jee paper and board mill) Aman Garh, Nizampur Cement Company (AWT), Fauji Corn Complex at Jehangira, Nowshera Sheet Glass Industries at Adamzai, Pakistan Tobacco Company at Akora Khattak, Associated Industries Ltd. at Amangarh, Ferozsons pharmaceutical at Amangarh, Locomotive factory at Risalpur, and Special Export Processing Zone at Risalpur.  The contamination primarily resulted from DDT production in a local factory that was established in 1963 and remained in operation until 1994. The main factory drain led to the Kabul river and nearby villages. Studies have determined that both the water and soil in and around the factory area are still contaminated with DDT, despite the closure of the factory 12 years ago. The contamination within the factory area poses a threat to public health and the environment and has serious consequences to ecosystem functions, food safety, and other aspects of human health.  The area/soil may remain contaminated with DDT for some time and researchers have strongly recommended that the land near the factory should not be sold or put to use without prior approval from an environmental impact assessment of the DDT factory.   The annual production of the factory when in operation was about 6000 tons. In 1994, the factory was closed after ban on the use of 21 pesticides including DDT. But still the nauseating smell of DDT is clear as one nears this industry.  Most of the houses in the vicinity of the factory were found to be made of cement and stone bricks. The standards of living are not very high and mostly people are indulged in professions like factory labors, Government servants etc. Transportation is also a common business.    From the nominator:  "The DDT factory and the site proposed for the present study are in Nowshera Peshawar, North West Frontier Province (NWFP), Pakistan (33o.10` to 34o.10` north latitudes and 71o.39` to 72o.16` east longitudes).    Data described in two SDPI reports indicates that 90.91% of the soil samples studied (90 soil samples in a half kilometer square area) were contaminated with DDT, with 66.6% of the samples indicating residual DDT levels higher than DDT minimum risk level in soil."        Humans can come in contact with DDT through contaminated air, soil, water and food.
health_impact: Cancer, male infertility , learning disabilities in children.  DDT is persistent in nature and does not degrade in the environment by biological, physical, or chemical processes. Being non biodegradable, DDT can travel to long distances (thousands of kilometers ) and can accumulate in human bodies due to its solubility in fats. Even in very minute amounts DDT can injure human health and health of other organisms. It is harmful to stomach, intestines, liver and kidneys and can affect nervous system and can cause reproductive, development defects and cancer and tumors. It also causes learning disabilities in children. Women, children and infants are especially vulnerable to certain effects of DDT.    It is evident from the previous studies that both water and soil in the surrounding areas of the factory are contaminated by DDT, despite the fact the factory was closed more than a decade before. Keeping in view the persistency, non biodegradability, environmental impacts of DDT in and around the factory area pose serious threat to the public health and environment.  Fetus and unborn babies are badly affected by absorption of the accumulated DDT in the fats of their parents bodies.
notes: DDT (Dichloro diphenyl trichloroethane) is one of the most hazardous groups of chemicals called Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs), also known as "The Dirty Dozen". These very toxic chemicals, including DDT are long lasting due to their non-degradability, can travel to distant places and being fat soluble, accumulate in animals and human bodies. Even in extremely small amounts, POPs cause adverse impacts on human health and environment.   To save public health, especially the health of the children, the manufacturing and use of POPs has been banned in the world under the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs), enacted in 2001. A number of national governments including Pakistan have signed the Stockholm Convention. The Convention has been ratified by over 120 countries thus far. Due to the persistent nature of DDT, a persistent organic pollutant and its adverse environmental and health impacts, a study was undertaken by SDPI Research Team to examine the residual DDT in and around a DDT manufacturing factory in Amman Gharh, Nowshera, and NWFP.   The main crops of the area are Wheat, sugar cane, maize, sugar beet. Fruits like plum, pear, sweet orange, lemon, peach, apricot, guava etc are also grown frequently.   According to the 1998 census of Pakistan the population of the area was 874,373, a population density of 500.2 persons per km². The annual growth rate was 2.9% and the proportion of urban dwellers was 26%.Muslims form 99% of the population, of the rest, Christian 0.5%; Ahmadi 0.3% and Hindu 0.1%. The main Language is Pushto (91%) followed by Punjabi (3.6%) and Urdu (1.3%) - the literacy rate is 89%
strategy: The soil of the factory area is still contaminated with DDT. So the factory area should not be sold for any other purpose or put to any other use without NWFP Environmental Protection Agency ’s permission.   The factory area should be declared dangerous zone and banned for human activities and other interferences.   Cost Effective activated charcoal or biochemical methods should be investigated for the site remediation     Awareness campaigns should be raised in the area   KEY PLAYERS: SDPI  TIME FRAME: 6 months

Using Low-Cost Iron Byproducts from Automotive Manufacturing to Remediate DDT Finding a cheaper and easily available iron source is one way of making this technology more affordable for field application.  2. Bioremediation using fungal or algal biomass  KEY PLAYERS: SDPI, NWFP EPA, Local Government  TIME FRAME: 2-3 YEARS
barriers: No social barriers as such faced in the area. The local district government is fully supportive and through official notification has already declared the land banned for any commercial or residential activities.

name: Procter & Gamble - Jurubatuba - SP
one_sentence: Update - 2016:  Degreasers from an old battery plant in the south part of São Paulo have contaminated the groundwater with a variety of organics compounds. The contamination passed the limits of the factory and contaminated the soil and groundwater and the free aquifer with halogenated solvents. There is consumption of contaminated groundwater by the population living near the site, even though they were prohibited to open wells, some still do.
description: Update - 2016: This area is located at Rua Eusébio Estevaux, 2105, Jurubatuba, in the south part of the city of São Paulo. From 1980 to 1993, Duracell Company, a battery manufacturer, used the area to degrease battery covers mainly with chlorinated solvents. Gillett bought Duracell and later Duracell is bought by Procter & Gamble. The cholorinated solvents leached from the area or their waste was buried and ended up contaminating soil and the water aquifer outside the limits of the company. In 1999, the contamination was found in several residential wells and three wells in the Mall. People are exposed to the water and vapors from the ground. After almost 20 years the area remains to be remediated.  ______________________________________________________________________________  Previous information:  Gillette of Brazil (Procter & Gamble of Brazil Ltda.) Currently called Procter & Gamble of Brazil S/A, the old Gillette company is located to the Avenue Eusobio Stevaux, 2105. It is a residential area with great flow of people daily. The contamination was originated from the activities of the old one proprietor of the land, the Duracell company, who carried through, between 1984 and 1993 degreasers, it of covers of solvent batteries with chlorinated. In November of 2001, the company communicated spontaneously to the CETESB the confirmation of contamination of the ground and underground waters in its property.   The residues of the contamination are being removed of the place and destined for incineration in company TRIBEL in the Rio De Janeiro State, company that already possessed a contamination description and already it was condemned by the public prosecution service in 22 of October of 2009, having that to paralyze the act of receiving of residues of other states until a license for the IBAMA is forwarded, not to receive more products contend mercury and the payment of fine of U$ 1.178.897, 7306 that the ambient compensation will be destined (Papers - I.C.P n nº 1.30.017.000 070/2006-98). name: Revda-Pervoyralsk industrial hub
one_sentence: This heavily industrialized town of metallurgical industries, including a large copper smelter, is emitting air pollution with roughly 10x the recommended maximum level of benzo(a)pyrenes.
description: Revda is in the Sverdlovsk oblast, in the mid-Urals on the Revda River, at the confluence of the Chusovaya River. Founded in 1734 when a metallurgical factory was built, it became a city in 1935. In 1940 the Sredneuralsk copper-smelting plant began operations here. The Sredneuralsky copper smelter is responsible for about 957,000 tons of pollutant emissions per year.   http://www.ecocom.ru/arhiv/ecocom/NEAP/eng/Chapter1.htm   Industries in Revda emit 400-450 tons of lead per year. The level of lead in soil exceeds the  permissible allowable concentrations by more than 10 times.   http://www.chem.unep.ch/pops/POPs_Inc/proceedings/stpetbrg/kurlyand.htm  Intas conducted a 3 year study (from 1994-1997) involving the ecological monitoring of forests in polluted areas in the Sverdlovsk region. The study area covered an area of approximately 25 x 30 km around the city of Revda. The results of the study revealed high metal concentrations near the smelter as compared to background concentrations: copper-up to 90-115-fold, lead up to 15-21-fold, zinc up to 10-19-fold and cadmium up to 10-16-fold. The soil contamination index K which is displayed by how many times the various pollutants measured exceeded the background level, reached as high as 128 at these sites.  http://www.intas.be/catalog/93-1645.HTM  The Chusovaya River is also extremely polluted by the effluents of the Sredneuralsky copper smelter. In 1996 the average annual concentration of copper compounds in the river’s water was 116 MACs; hexavalent chromium, 33 MACs; manganese, 15 MACs; zinc 15 MACs; iron 5 MACs. name: Nanan Village, Guiyu Town, Shantou City, Guangdong Province
one_sentence: Electronic waste recycling practices are contaminating the air, water, and soil with heavy metals in Guiyu Town. Nanan Village, located in the west of Guiyu Town, has been specifically affected by chromium.
description: Electronic waste recycling practices are contaminating the air, water, and soil with heavy metals in Guiyu Town. Nanan Village, located in the west of Guiyu Town, has been specifically affected by chromium. Guiyu Town is an electronic trash city. Every day more than 100 freight vehicles, filled with loaded waste electric parts, comes into the small towns. The annual mean temperature is 21.4 degrees Celsius. The yearly average precipitation is 13,864 millimeters.       Nanan village is located at the west of Guiyu Town, where people resorted to all means to gain the recycled and used metal. In Nanan village shiny black ponds send out an odour, and the village is also fluttered with smoke continuously.      Here, air is suffocating, river water is polluted, and soil is poisoned. The serious contaminated ecological environment has also impaired villagers' health. Many labors were infected with respiratory disease, skin ulcers, even cancer.  They burn down the worn out electric wire and the electric cable with the sulfur acid water flushing circuit wafer. They burn down trash which are unable to be recycled again, and piled it up near the river.
health_impact: Shantou University Medical School of Guangdong Province took the physical examination to the non-native population of Guiyu Town and discovered that 88% people have skin disease and contracted diseases of the nervous system, respiratory system and digesting system.  Mr. Lin who lived in the Nanan village said: "The villagers are breathing the dirty air, their body is very bad, many people have the breath and skin disease. Some people used the polluted water to wash vegetables and the tableware, therefore they had gastric disease, and other one kind of common disease was a kidney stone."

name: Kizel Coal Basin
one_sentence: Mining in the area of Kizel Coal Basin has released intensive heavy metals into the region. Although the mine has closed, acidic effluents are still polluting the ground, rivers, and air with chromium.
description: One of the most acute environmental problems of the West Urals region is a consequence of the cessation of mining in the area of the Kizel Coal Basin. High concentrations of iron, aluminum and trace metals in the region are due to the geochemical features of the Carboniferous strata. The coal of this basin differs from that of other basins in the former USSR, mainly because it contains large contents of sulfur (5.8%, mainly as pyrite) and ash (21.5%).  After the closure of the mine, acidic mine waters (with a pH of about 3) began to pollute the soil and rivers. Within the last five years, the tributaries of the Kama and Chusovaya Rivers have become highly polluted with dissolved metals such as iron and aluminum. In the more polluted sections of the rivers, accumulations of several tones of man-made bottom deposits have been found.  These accumulations include amorphous iron and aluminum hydroxides along with high concentration of Mn, Cu, Ni, Zn, Pb and others metals. These bottom deposits are washed downstream to the Kama and the Chusovaya Rivers, where they become a secondary source of water pollution.              People are affected primarily by drinking water contaminated with metals. Particulates in the air are also of concern.
health_impact: Translation:  Mortality in Kizel is the highest in the Perm region.  In 2008, it amounted to 27.3% of the population, and the principal causes of death were diseases of the circulatory system. These diseases, in general, affect 47% of the population.  Diseases of the digestive system were found in  13% of the population. The next most common afflictions were "neoplasms" and "respiratory diseases," at 10% and 8% respectively. The infant mortality rate trend over the past 10 years is that of a decline (growth rate - (-18%)), but remains significant. The mortality of children under 1 year old in 2008 was 15.7%. A significant increase in the incidence of "neoplasms" was observed, especially in children. The life expectancy in the Kizel population is the lowest in the province. In 2008, life expectancy at birth for the total population was 55.95 (females - 62.8,  males - 50.05). One survey found that the health status of children in the villages is characterized by multiorgan failure.  Through chemical analysis of toxins in the blood of residents in these mining towns, significant levels of heavy metals--such as copper, nickel, manganese, and lead--were found at levels significantly above the regional background concentrations.  This information was provided by experts at the Perm Scientific-Research Clinical Institute of Child ekopatologii. name: Shell Brasil Ltda - Vila Carioca - SP
one_sentence: Update - 2016 The company Shell do Brasil Ltda contaminated the soil in Vila Carioca, São Paulo, buy burying waste from oil, detergents used to clean tanks and organochloride pesticides (only manufactured by Shell in Brazil). These substances leached to areas outside the company and contaminated the soil, eventually reaching the free aquifer. The houses near the area had many wells and people used the water to drink, cook, irrigate their plantations and feed animals.   ____________________________________________________________________ Previous information: The improper storage of waste tanks by the Shell Brasil Ltda. company contaminated the air, soil, and groundwater of Vila Carioca with volatile organic compounds, polychlorinated biphenyls, and primarily poly aromatic hydrocarbons.
description: Update - 2016:  Shell Brasil Ltda was located at Av. Auriverde, 2028 - Vila Carioca – Ipiranga district - São Paulo.  Shell had two adjacent areas in Vila Carioca, one was used for storage of oil and of organochlorine solvents and the other, the Shell Sport Clube, was a social area for workers with soccer field and restaurant. This area had been where the company manufactured pesticides from 1972 to 1976.  The inadequate disposal of these substances caused the contamination of soil and water outsite the limits of the company.  Until 1985, most of the houses near Shell had wells. This water was used for cooking, for watering small plantations, and feeding pigs and chickens. There was no pavement on the streets. So, it is plausible to say that the population was exposed from water and soil contact.  ______________________________________________________________________________ Previous information:  Shell Brasil Ltda is located in a busy transit area with many houses in the capital of the country. This region has many rivers, abundant canals throughout the city, and groundwater reserves. Contamination poses a great potential risk here due to the types of pollutant and the fact that the contaminants have reached the air and the groundwater inside and outside the limits of the company. The ground and subsoil near the company have also been contaminated.   The company designed its activities to store organo-chlorides and the problem was caused by the burial of Shell's combustible waste tanks - the so called dregs - in the region, and from scraps from their own tanks. name: Xianma Village, Guiyu Town, Shantou City, Guangdong Province
one_sentence: Electronic waste recycling has heavily polluted Guiyu Town with high concentrations of heavy metals. Residents of Xianma Village have been especially affected by chromium pollution in their water source.
description: At the site, air was suffocated, river water was polluted, soil was poisoned. The serious contaminated ecological environment has also impaired villagers' health. Many labors were infected the respiratory disease, the skin presented ulcer, even had cancer. It is in the South Asian tropics climate region; the annual mean temperature is 21.4 degrees C, and the yearly average precipitation is 13,864 millimeters.       Guiyu Town is an electronic trash city. Every day more than 100 freight vehicles loaded full of waste electronic parts visit the small towns. Xianma village is located south of Guiyu Town. People resorts to all means to gain recycled and used metals. The primary method involves nearly burning down the worn out electric wires and the electric cables, and with the sulfuric acid water flushing the circuit wafer. Burnt down trash, unable to be recycled again, are piled up nearby the river. In Xianma village shiny black ponds containing the waste were spewing odor.       In a crude storehouse, a row of people often sit before the bunker and burn the circuit boards under a dim light. The equipment that are used is crude: pliers, gloves, cups of tap water, and very rarely, face masks. The only safety equipment was a ventilator, but in the summer heat and the odors from toxic air can be suffocating.   Air from burning/water from waste
health_impact: Shantou University Medical school of Guangdong Province took physical examinations of the non-native population of Guiyu Town and discovered that 88% people have problems including skin disease, nervous system problems, respiratory illnesses, stomach illnesses, etc.  Lai Yun, who is a Greenpeace project Director said that many labors have respiratory illnesses and skin ulcers.
notes: no
strategy: 1. In order to stop pollution, the government public proclamation forbids to burn down, heating and acid pickling, the destruction bunker, they also has established the supervising group momentarily.   2. When the assistant inspector Li Jing of the national Development and Planning Commission environment and resources comprehensive utilization department inspected the Guiyu town and pointed out that Guiyu must continue the formalization, the standardization and the scientific style.   3. The country information industrial department already authorized Guiyu to set up the waste electronic information product solution processing demonstration project, the Economic and Trade Committee also to report to national Development and Planning Commission made Guiyu as the waste electronic information product solution and use demonstration base.  timeframe: about 5 years.
remediation_plan: 1. In the source reduces diligently discards  2. Recycling and detoxification processes  3. soil remediation by plants.   timeframe: about 10 years.
barriers: Lack of funds to remediation; the technology is not mature.

name: Khojohasan Lake, Absheron Rayon, Azerbaijan
one_sentence: Khojasan Lake is located very close to Baku and Khojasan town. Sampling results show that water, bottom sediments and soil in close areas are characterized by heavy arcenic and cadmium contaminants. There are many other contaminants both in water and sediments. The lake level has risen due to the influx of waste water generated from the excavation and operation of oil and gas wells on the west shore, waste water from Khojahasan settlement and agriculture. Pollution Pathways include food, dermal contact, fishing and inhalation.
description: Lake Khojahasan is an inland body of salt water in a valley next to Baku. According to the Worldbank survey, the maximum depth is 3.4 meters. The lake is located at 28 meters below sea level and has a surface area of approximately 182 hectares.The lake feeds from precipitation and is completely severed from any rivers. In recent years the lake water level has risen due to the influx of waste water generated from the excavation and operation of oil and gas wells on the west shore, waste water from Khojahasan settlement and agriculture.  In order to determine pollution levels, we took samples both from water and sediments. Samples were analyzed in the chemical laboratory of the Ministry of Ecology and Natural resources.  Results confirm heavy Cadmium and Arsenic contamination. Phenol and Lead concentrations are also high.  All of these compounds are highly toxic and may cause lung, skin and cancer diseases.  According to official statistics, lung diseases in the area are common.     Pathways include food, inhalation, and skin contact. many people come here to fishing. Also, the areas is used as a beach so people may become ill from using the water for recreational purposes.
health_impact: A local doctor talked about high levels of cancer, which is not known. This could be related to pollutants in the lake. In the past there were documented impacts on human health due too pollution. However, officials say the new technology that was introduced prevents pollution. So far, health effects are not well documented and require detailed study.
strategy: 1. The first task would be preventing of the pollution that comes from residential areas and old oil wells coming into the lake. 2. The surface contaminants should be transported into an isolated area. Then contaminated soil may be cleaned using bio-remediation or other possible methods. 3. Special collectors and oxidation methods can be used to remove toxic metals from the water.
remediation_plan: 1-2 year would be enough to clean surface contaminants. However bioremediation activities for all levels of the lake may take longer.

name: Sahraul village, Sector -18, Gurgaon, Haryana, India
one_sentence: The groundwater in Sahraul Village is contaminated with Chromium from local industry waste.  While some villagers buy water tankers, others rely on the groundwater for drinking. The site was visited in 2014 by India Coordinator and informed that the polluting unit is underrating groundwater remediation and people are not using water sources any more.
description: Gurgaon is situated in the southeastern part of Hayrana state and has an area of 3,852 sq.km.  It is surrounded by the Union Territory of Delhi in the north, by Uttar Pradesh in the east, by the Jhajjar and Rewai districts of Haryana and the Alwar district of Rajasthan State in the west, and by the Mewat district of Haryana in the south. Gurgaon is largely comprised of alluvial plains and traversed by elongated ridges of delhi quartzites.  The climate of the area is tropical steppe, semi-arid and hot, while in the monsoon season a moist air penetrates in the district which causes high humidity.  Annual rainfall= 596mm(2007 data) Normal monsoon rainfall= 508mm (2007 data)  The topography of Gurgaon district is flat, and the soil texture is medium loamy sand. No rivers are found in Gurgaon. The water supply is based on groundwater through tube wells.  The groundwater is mostly unsuitable for drinking due to natural alkaline and saline.  Upon visiting Sahraul village, our investigators found that the ground water contains Hexavelant Chromium and a high percentage of Nickel. Residents believe that the source of the pollution is M/S Munjal Showa, a factory engaged in electroplating processes and manufacturing of shock absorbers for two and three wheelers. The villagers complained that the industry discharges untreated effluent through boreholes. The contamination of water was discovered in 2007, but no action was taken.   Gurgaon is an industrial and BPO hub. It has been noted that the village is occupied by 20,000 permanent villagers and 100,000 immigrants. Almost 2,000-2,500 people are at risk due to drinking and bathing in the untreated water. The immigrants mainly are from the labor class and are fully dependent on the groundwater. As described by Mr. Mahavir Yadav, within a 500m periphery from the village the ground water is totally affected by the chromium.   The village has 8 tube wells, out of which 6 are affected and only 2 are in working condition.   Villagers said that Munjal Showa receives 250 water tankers each day and draws it out of the bore well.  Villagers purchase Rs.500 of water tankers a day and Rs.50 for besleri dispensers per day. However, the labor class immigrants still depend on the ground water.    Villagers are suffering from skin rashes and severe vomiting. According to Medical experts, consumption of water with high levels of chromium could lead to renal, kidney and liver failure and also liver, kidney and stomach cancer and skin diseases.  According to the villagers there are no industries nearby except BPOs and garments industries.  (Newspaper article attached)                          Water is the pathway and pollutants are spread through drinking, bathing, and food.
health_impact: skin rashes due to bathing  (Photo attached)
notes: On 5.06.2009 Haryana State Pollution Control Board collected water from the tubewells. The water collected from the tubewells of Mr. Mahavir Yadav was yellowish in colour. Water was also collected from the tubewell of the facility premises and it was found that yellowish water was coming from the tubewell.  The report released by the Panchukla Laboratory shows Hexavelant Chromium in the water (82.34 mg/l)   Base Kitchen is a facility that provides cooked food to the BPOs and other MNCs. An interviewee said that they use groundwater to prepare food.  Though we don't have any other reports, if this is true it means that pollutants are indirectly going into the food chain.
strategy: Haryana State Pollution control Board (HSPCB)had already put across a notice against the unit.   Short term strategies: Proper monthly monitoring and site evaluation should be done by the pollution control baord  Water tankers to be provied to the affected area.  Proper free Health check ups need to be done by the government body
remediation_plan: Effluent treatment plant or reverse osmosis plant should be made compulsory to each industrial setup.
barriers: According to the villagers, political barriers are there. As M/s Munjal Showa Ltd. manufactures shock absorbers for the Hero Honda and Maruti Uduog.companies so they have political support.

name: Poblado La Rinconada
one_sentence: The village La Rinconada is affected by mercury pollution resulting from artisanal gold mining. The community does not have safe drinking water, drainage, or sanitary landfills.
description: The village La Rinconada is affected by mercury pollution resulting from artisanal gold mining.  The community of La Rinconada is located in the Ananea district, Province of San Antonio de Putina in the department of Puno, in the highlands of Peru at more than 5,400 m, at 220 km from Puno City and 1317 km from Lima. This zone covers an area of approximately 200 km2.  This village is one of the highest in the world and is located in the Ananea snowcapped, mountain glacier, where temperatures reach to -25 oC. There are many rivers, rainfall, snowfall and hail. The Ananea snowcapped peaks have much gold contained in veins, and to access the mineral you must open tunnels using picks, drills or explosives.   This community lives with gold mining on a small and informal scale, and including the refining of gold is done at home. They do not have safe drinking water, drainage, or sanitary landfills. The people live in overcrowded houses, rustic.  They have a medical post and some educational institutions, but all are in the midst of mine tailings containing mercury and other toxic substances, household waste and excreta.  The mountains belong to the Peruvian state, which leases them to mining companies in the area who pollute the environment and affect to people permanently. In addition, many of the tailings generated by the extraction of minerals are used by women and children in the area looking for gold remains by using mercury in the open to obtain pure gold.  They Use 2g of mercury per gram gold. This causes tje release of mercury gases that affect the community. Lately, they are using machinery such as backhoes and electric turnstiles to increase gold production and consequently there is more pollution. Each year they produce approximately 3 tons of gold for 6 tons of mercury.  The activities also pollute the Cumuni lake and Riticucho glacial, which are used as water sources for the majority, but many households consume water from the melting of the ceiling due to their poverty. Besides, the streets of La Rinconada are flooded by fluids circulating tailings and streams to reach the nearest river, which flow into Titicaca lake, affecting crops and livestock and thousands of people living near the lake.                water, soil, air
health_impact: There are no studies on toxicity in the population, but by the presence of mercury, cyanide and other toxins in the area, and because the most people consume contaminated water, the people would have these substances in your body.
strategy: It has implemented a recovery system of mercury in the process of amalgamation. But, do not have any plan to remedy the area.

Lead dust are polluting the soils of nearby residential and commercial areas.

name: Mollah Metal (Lead breaking & smelting) Works , Sadhapur, Bongaon, Savar, Dhaka
one_sentence: The investigated site is a battery recycling site in the rural area and a source of pollution for soil, air and water due to breaking of used battery and lead smelting. Lead and arsenic are the main pollutant and probable pathways of toxic metals are dermal contact and inhalation/ingestion.
description: This is a local ULAB breaking and smelting site situated at Bilbagil, Sadhapur, Bongaon union of Savar upazila, Dhaka district.   They break used batteries and sort out different parts of the batteries for recycling. They smelt lead at this site in an open place.   This area is a sparsely populated alluvial agricultural plain land. There is a river close to the site.  Lead and arsenic is the main pollutant of this area which are polluting the air,soil and water of nearby areas. People are exposed to lead and arsenic toxicity through dermal contact and inhalation/ingestion.

name: Judi River, Kathari-9 VDC (Naya Bazaar), Morang
one_sentence: Various production industries are discharging their untreated effluents into the Judi River. This is contaminating the surface water, groundwater, air, and agricultural soils with chromium.
description: Kathari-9 VDC, Naya Bazaar is located in Morang district in the eastern region of Nepal. It is located in the Terai region where the land is mostly flat. The general climate is very hot and dry. The major water system flowing through the area is the Judi River, which flows across the border into India.   Many industries such as the leather industry, soap industry, chemical industry, and textile industry are severely polluting the river and its banks by directly discharging their untreated waste water and solid waste.  This has contaminated the surface water, groundwater, air, and agricultural soils.          * Surface Water - Dermal * Groudwater - Oral * Soil - Dermal * Air - Inhalation/ Dermal
health_impact: * Respiratory Problem * Skin related diseases * nasal septum perforation * dermatitis * gangrene etc  1 ) According to Mr. Shankar Lal Dev, a medical shop owner (Shankar medical shop, Kathari-9 VDC, Naya Bazaar), a large number of patients suffer from liver cancer, skin related diseases, asthma, diarrhea, jaundice, and malaria. Two people have died in the past year from liver cancer.  The local populace living near the industrial area also reports similar health problems faced by the community dwellers  2) The regional Directorate of Agricultural Development office and the local community dwellers also reported that many domestic animals had died by drinking water from Judi River. This issue had been raised and published in the newspapers but no actions were taken against it.  3) The foul smell was also evident during our site visit  4) Mr Ram charitra Sah, staff scientist, had visited the industries in 2003. He reported that he had skin irritation for six months.
notes: Likely Transmission path continued...  Judi River receives a huge amount of untreated industrial waste from different types of industries, namely, Tannery, Soap and chemical, and Textile operating within its banks.  The area largely consists of agricultural fields and the farmers basically use the river water for irrigation purpose. Besides, the water is also used for bathing and washing.  Most people working in the agricultural fields do not use any safety measures and come directly into contact with the soil. People, mostly children, walk barefoot.   There is a high risk of this hazardous waste water getting mixed up with the ground water, which is drawn out by the locals using tube wells and dug wells for drinking.  Hazardous wastes dumped outside the industry area produce very strong and foul odor.
strategy: * Increase awareness on pollution problem and health impacts among all stakeholders.   * Construction of a Chromium treatment plant.  * Proper dumping site development.  Key players: Local Municipal authorities, Community Dwellers, Industry owner and workers  Time frame - This can be done over a period of six months to 1 year.
remediation_plan: * Setting up an industrial zone with    adequate treatment facilities  * Effective monitoring by Government agencies
barriers: * Lack of awareness among the stakeholders on the glaring pollution problem and its severe health impacts   * Lack of social initiatives  * Lack of commitment from the concerned government agencies  * Deficiency of infrastructures and expertise  * Financial constraints

name: Parque metropolitano Pituaçu (Lagoa Pituaçu) - BA
one_sentence: The lagoon of Pituaçu is located in the Metropolitan Park of Pituaçu (PMP). It receives domestic effluents and rainwater and is in an accelerated process of environmental degradation. According to Silva et al., 2016, the concentrations found for Mn were between 44 and 481.5 mg/kg, indicating possible needs to expand environmental monitoring actions. The water, sediment, and soil are considered contaminated. Visitors and park staff may be exposed by dermal contact, inhalation, and ingestion due to fishing along the pond.
description: The Metropolitan Park of Pituaçu is located between four important avenues of Salvador, which are Luís Viana Filho, Pinto de Aguiar, Otávio Mangabeira and Jorge Amado. Its location is close to the sea. Its institutional area has approximately 660 hectares and the effective one, which comprises the Park itself, is about 400 hectares. A significant part of this total (100 hectares) corresponds to the water's mirror of the dam and the rest, to the hills bordering it. Some of its natural characteristics - soil, relief, vegetation and water quality, for example - have already suffered anthropic action due to the initial occupation by farms or farms, the recent urbanization of its surroundings and the installation of equipment inside. In the surroundings there is an economic center of the capital (Iguatemi), Luís Eduardo Magalhães Airport and the Administrative Center of Bahia (CAB), as well as the direct relationship with the main road corridor of the city (BR-324 / Paralela) and the expansion area that was formed along this.  Also there are a restaurant next to park. The lagoon is surrounded by a cycle path of 18 km (SEMA, 2015). Near the lake, many people do various activities, children play in the playgrounds, frequent snack bars inside the park. Although this lagoon is located in an area of environmental preservation can be perceived in it signs of pollution, possibly arising from the disposal of solid waste from anthropic activities related to domestic and industrial waste.

name: Kalu River area, Maharashtra
one_sentence: An industrial belt of over 100 production units between Mumbai and Kaylan is contaminating the Kalu River with mercury, lead, cadmium, and chromium.
description: The Kalu River is located in the state of Maharashtra of western India and originates in the Western Ghats. It is located northeast of the district of Thane and runs between the cities of Mumbai and Kaylan and through the industrial suburbs of Ambarnath, Ulhasnagar, and Ambivli. Within this stretch of roughly 45 km, the river accumulates the effluents from over 100 industrial units, many of which produce rayon, aluminum, iron, steel, petrochemicals, pesticides, pharmaceuticals, and fungicides.  A series of investigations by Ramani Rao and Dr B.C. Haldar for the Institute of Science in Mumbai revealed the presence of heavy metals in the aquatic environment of the Kalu River. The scientists examined a 10 km stretch of the Kalu between Ambivali and Titwala, surveying the water quality and effect of the industrial waste on plant and animal life.   They found heavy metals such as mercury, lead, copper, and cadmium in the river water, along with chlorides, dyes, and organic acids. Sediments along the bank also showed fairly high concentrations of mercury, lead, cadmium, and copper.   More recent studies continue to show levels of mercury 100x over the recommended maximum.
health_impact: Generally health related adverse effects are observed after chronic exposure to low doses. Some of the health effects due to heavy metal toxicity may be like this:   Arsenic causes Periferal neuropathy,dermatitis,digestive disturbances; while Cadmium could cause Respiratory disorders, kidney damage, anaemia and hypertension. Lead has been known to cause Abdominal colic, anaemia, neuropathy and Manganese-Encephalopathy. Chromium may cause Dermatitis, ulceration and gastrointestinal symptoms. Mercury could lead to Kidney damage and neuropathy.  There have been epidemics of Hg poisoning from the consumption of fish from polluted Kalu River in the Thana district of Bombay, India. The major symptom amongst those afflicted was paralysis.  Likewise, mercury enters the food chain, poisoning the fish and the cattle that graze on plants in shallow water. The pycreus plants, the most abundant form of vegetation in Ambivali, showed high concentrations of heavy metals. The leaves of these plants contained 3 to 110 ppm of mercury. The rhizomes of the same plants contained 6.9 to 53.3 ppm.   The investigation also found 5 ppm of mercury in the milk of the cattle that graze on these plants. A child drinking a liter of this milk every day would be consuming 35 ppm mercury per a week. Over a period of several months this could accumulate to over 0.3 mg of mercury, which is well above the safe level.   See attached report.
notes: One study found that mercury concentrations up to 612 mg/g have been found in fish living in the Kalu River (1).  Another found heavy accumulation of mercury, lead, and cadmium in the dominant plant species (Pycreus macrostachyos) in the Kalu region (2).   sources:  1) Jhingran, V., g. (1983) Fisheries and Water Pollution. In: Water Pollution and Management (ed. C. K. Varshney), 166-186. Wiley Eastern Ltd., New Delhi.  2) Mhatre et al. "Effect of industrial pollution on the Kalu river ecosystem." Environmental Pollution Series A, Ecological and Biological. 23 (1980): 67-78.

name: Gikondo industrial zone Wstern  part
description: Located in Gikondo wetland  in Kigali City, this industrial area covers a total area of 280 hectares (source: Department of physical planning Kigali City).   Gikondo Park contains metallurgical and manufacturing industries. The environmental impacts associated with the processing process are many. The following examples are to be cited: effluent discharge, waste water and solid waste, hazardous and toxic waste; however, most of the old industries at Gikondo are to be relocated to  a new  planned area for industrial zone, and this was decided by the Government of Rwanda to reduce the environmental impact of these industries in the wetland.   Gikondo western part(Volta Super factory) The factory is located on the one slope of Gikondo valley, near the main road and Kicukiro-Gkondo-Kigali city center. This is the main factory for manufacturing a great quantity of Nickel cadmium batteries most used in the country.  The factory has been put in place in   a part of waste water used from manufacturing and washing, and cleaning inside of the factory is evacuated through the sewage channel situated near the secondary road going in Gikondo valley, where it is used by some people in washing clothes. Another part of waste water infiltrates into the groundwater, a leading natural source situated at the bottom of the hill, where many people unable to buy water all around the factory come to fetch water for cooking, washing dishes and their clothes. And the worst element is that much of this water from the springs and sewage channel ends up in Nyabugogo wetland channels and Nyabugogo River.  The environmental impact and human sanitation associated with that waste water are many. name: Kerbs & Cies Ltd (KCL) & East Coast Fertilizers Ltd (ECFC), Mayurbhanj District, Orissa
one_sentence: Leachate and runoff from dump sites used by the now-closed Kerbs & Cies Ltd and East Coast Fertilizers Ltd facilities is contaminating the agricultural soil of Balasore. The contaminants of concern are hexavalent chromium and sulfate.
description: M/s Kerbs & Cies Limited (KCL) & M/s East Coast Fertilizers Limited (ECFL) are located in Mayurbhanj District, about 10 kms to the city of Balasore (also known as Baleswar or Baleshwar) in the Orissa state of eastern India. Both are abandoned sites and are located about 1 k from each other at the National Highway 5, which connects Balasore & Baripada.  KCL was operational from 1983 to 1998, and during this time manufactured basic chrome sulfate (BCS) with an installed production capacity of 4800 TPA. During its operational period, it generated hazardous wastes that contained chromium. As per the National Productivity Council Report on Investigation and Remediation of Old Hazardous waste Dumps in Orissa, there are five identified dumps (two outside and three inside) within the industry premises, which covers an estimated area of 1200 square meters, which itself contains approximately 4200 tons of hazardous waste.   The area where the waste is dumped reportedly belongs to the owner. There is only a fenced wall at the front of the premises; the other three sides are left open, unprotected. Yellow-colored wastes and soils were seen scattered around many places around the abandoned structures and broken kiln, which indicates a high concentration of CrVI. The drainage paths were also found to be contaminated. It seems that during the rains, leachate is generated and the run-off overflows into the surrounding area, contaminating the nearby agricultural plots.  M/s Krebs & Cie Ltd  (Site KCL-I), Mayurbhanj , Orissa  The generated wastes were dumped on various sites existing inside and outside the unit. The site KCL-I is inside the premises of M/s KCL near H2SO4 tanks. The approximate total area under waste at all sites in 12000 sq.m and quantity of waste lying at sites is around 42000 MT.  For KCL-I: Area 4000 Sqm Average Depth 2.5 m 10000m3 (15000MT) *Bulk density of 1.5T/m3  It was engaged in manufacturing of chrome salt since 1983. The unit has been closed since 1998. The major product of the unit was basic chrome sulphate with installed production capacity of 4800 TPA. During operational period, the unit was generating hazardous waste containing chromium.     Likewise, during its operation until 2003, East Coast Fertilizers Ltd manufactured single super phosphate (SSP) and sulphuric acid. The unit was forced to close by the Board at the request of locals who were protesting against the contamination of their paddy fields.  During the investigation, two uncovered dumps were noticed, one outside the boundary and one near the cooling unit. A raw sulphur-dump was found inside the facility. An abundance of gypsum waste was noticed near the dismantled sheds. Spent vanadium (catalyst in the process) was found mixed into the waste at the second-dump. It is, however, not toxic as per Schedule 2 of Hazwaste Rules.  The locals are reportedly taking this muck from KCL to fill low-lying lands and thus are spreading the contamination to other places.  The ECFL Industry owner has sold the property. The new owner decided to open a school here, for which he did not need permission from the OPCB.  (Reported by Kadam group recently in 2013 that the two uncovered dumps were are still there; one outside the boundary and one near the cooling unit. A raw sulphur-dump was found inside the facility. An abundance of gypsum waste was noticed near the dismantled sheds. Spent vanadium (catalyst in the process) was found mixed into the waste at the second-dump. ECFC-I(Inside the premises) Area- 400 sqm, Avg Depth- 1 m, 400 m3 i.e 600 MT of waste (considering bulk density of 1.5 T/m3)  ECFC-II(Outside the premises along the boundary) Area- 1500 sqm, Avg Depth- 1 m, 1500 m3 i.e 2250 MT of waste (considering bulk density of 1.5 T/m3)   The suspected pathway to the human population is through soil contamination and runoff. Villages here are about 2-3 km from the sites and are reportedly using the pond waters for bathing purposes. However, the extent of groundwater contamination to affect food crops remains to be determined.
health_impact: People can be exposed through breathing contaminated air or ingesting food or water contaminated with chromium from soil or sediments.   • The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services has determined that certain chromium compounds are carcinogens.  • Chromium can damage the lungs, and cause allergic responses in the skin or asthma attacks. (ATSDR)
strategy: Digging the dumps and taking the waste to the TSDF facility under construction at Kalinganagar, District jajpur about 100 km from the site. The left over soil can be reclaimed using various bioremediation treatments.
remediation_plan: •Bioremediation of chromium (VI)contaminated aqueous systems by sulfate reducing bacteria (Source:http://www.freepatentsonline.com/5062956.html)  •Bioremediation of chromium (VI) contaminated solid residues:Chromium in solid waste residues may be immobilized by reduction of essentially all of the Cr(VI) to insoluble Cr(III). The Cr(VI) is separated from the solids by contacting with an acid to produce an aqueous solution having a pH of about 6.5 to 9.5, then adding sulfate-reducing anaerobic bacteria and, as required, a source of sulfates and nutrients for the growth of the bacteria. Where the solid residues are below the surface of the soil, a continuous recirculation may be established to extract Cr(VI), treat the resulting solution above grade to reduce Cr(VI) to Cr(III), and return the treated solution to the soil. (source:http://www.freepatentsonline.com/5155042.html)  •Bioremediation of toxic chromium from electroplating effluent by chromate-reducing Pseudomonas aeruginosa A2Chr in two bioreactors  (Source:http://www.springerlink.com/content/m6b8ake8k4y1kk1u/)  •Bioremediation of hexavalent chromium in soil microcosms (source:http://www.springerlink.com/content/lp2805523151r23h/)  The addition of dilute acetic acid or vinegar can help jumpstart bioremediation of chromium-contaminated industrial wastewater. (Source:http://www.biotech-weblog.com/50226711/bioremediation_of_chromiumcontaminated_waste_with_acetic_acid.php)
barriers: None

description: The Novocherkassk city has water streams as natural boundaries: Tuzlov River, Aksai River, and Grushevka River.  Aksai River is used as the source of centralized drinking water supply of the city. The northern part of the city (formerly Industrial District) is on the left slope of the Tuzlov River. Flood plain of the Tuzlov River does not have permanent buildings, but there are gardens and small temporary buildings. This is very densely populated area. 190,000 people live in the are of 50 square kilometers.   Novocherkassk is included in the 10 largest cities in the country with the highest concentration of industries per unit area. This creates environmental problems. Novocherkassk Electrode Plant is the largest plant for the production of graphite electrodes not only in Russia. This plant is one of the largest in Europe.  Coke and coal tar pitch are used as the main raw material in the plant. The plant usually uses carbon black, PTFE, talc, oleic acid, phenol, formalin, acids, alkalis. Carbon monoxide is the main component of emission. Hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide, hydrogen sulfide, and PAH get into the emissions too. More than 70 compounds (including benz(a)pyrene) were identified as a part of PAH. More than a thousand units of equipment is used at the plant. Not all equipment is equipped with gas- and dust collectors. (http://www.ecfor.ru/pdf.php?id=books/revich02/gor_t)  Benzo(a)pyrene is a priority pollutant for industrial district of Novocherkassk city. Its content in the groundwater ranges from 1 to 260 mg/l. Zones of emergency ecological situation were found near dumps and ponds of Novocherkassk Electrode Plant, on the area, also in residential areas Hotunok and Molodezhniy. Groundwater is contaminated with PAHs everywhere in Novocherkassk. Soils of Industrial District are highly polluted by PAHs with 4-7 nuclei. The max concentrations were on the area of Novocherkassk Electrode Plant and Plant "Kollak". The minimum concentrations were outside the industrial and residential areas (0.01-2.9 mg/kg). The tendency of reduces of PAH concentrations with increasing distance from the source (NEP) is obvious. PAH content in the soil of Pervomaysky District were significantly lower - 0,2-60 mg/kg. Concentration of benzo(a)pyrene were at the background levels (0,002-0,06 mg/kg). The high content of PAHs was found in the rivers. The highest concentrations were in drinking water source - Aksai river. name: Sanrorkuppam Lake, Ambur,  Vellore ,Tamilnadu
one_sentence: Leather tanneries used to dump waste, including chromium, directly into the Palar River traversing across Ambur. The water is no longer potable, but still used by the town and local High School for bathing, washing, and irrigation. Although there are now controls in place to prevent chromium dumping, the  Lake Ambur is still heavily polluted from legacy dumping.
description: The Sanrorkuppam lake is situated beside the National Hihgway 46 and opposite to a high school and a nearby tanneries & their ETPs   Ambur is located at 12Â°47â€²N 78Â°42â€²E12.78Â°N 78.7Â°E. It has an average elevation of 316 metres (1036 feet). Extremely hot and dry during summer when temperature soars to as high as 43 degree C (110 F). Winter is cold and dry with temperature dipping to 10 degree C during the night. Ambur is well connected by road, on the Chennai- Bangalore National Expressway, and by rail on the Chennai-Jolarpettai line with a number of express/superfast trains to Chennai, Bangalore, Coimbatore, Mysore, Erode, etc.Factories in Ambur manufacture shoes for world's leading footwear brand names like Floursheim, Lumberjack, Gabor, primigi, caterpillar, Clarks, Fretzmen, Coll Hann, Hi-Line, Hugo Boss, Marc, and many more. Hence, it is also known as a "Leather CityOne of the problems that Ambur faces is polluted ground water which is not potable. This happened due to the chemicals released by the leather tanneries directly into the most-of-the-time-dry Palar River traversing across Ambur before the Common Effluent Treatment Plants that use Reverse Osmosis process were installed. However, with strict measures taken by the State Government, most of the companies have now installed effluent treatment plants to treat the water from harsh chemicals such as hexavalent chromium, trivalent chromium, etc.         food,vegetables,drimking water,milk

notes: Mrs Malar, a milkmaid told the investigator that they never use the pond water for drinking or other household purposes.In rainy season they started suffering when the tanneries discharge their stored effluents that mix with the ground water.

name: Pavlodar
one_sentence: Soils beneath and adjacent to the Pavlodar Chemical Plant in Kazakhstan have been contaminated with elemental mercury as a result of chlor-alkali processing using mercury cathode cell technology.
description: Pavlodar is situated on the Irtysh river bank, on the northeast boundary between Russia and Kazakhstan. It is located 405 km southeast from the Russian city Omsk, and 440 km northeast of the capital, Astana.  Soils beneath and adjacent to the Pavlodar Chemical Plant in Kazakhstan have been contaminated with elemental mercury as a result of chlor-alkali processing using mercury cathode cell technology. The plant was closed in 1992, and its buildings have deteriorated since that time. Families now live around the industrial site.   Waters in the nearby Lake Balkyldak and the River Irtysh have high concentrations of mercury and fish from the waters are unfit for human consumption.   The issue of mercury contamination was recognized by the government and taken very seriously. In 1990s the government of Kazakhstan was seeking advice from national and international experts and looked for funds to implement the remediation project. The were several studies conducted by Kazakhstan and Russian specialists. The potential spreading of mercury contamination was modelled. A special "filtration wall" was constructed to prevent spreading of mercury further to the ground waters.  As indicated in most recent publication of Dr Panin on the area about half square kilometer there are about 900 metic tons of mercury. But in residential areas the concentrations of mercury are fairly low ranging from 0.08 to 18.96 ppm (Mercury in Snow and Soil of Pavlodar, Proceedings of the conference "Mercury in Biosphere", 7-9th of September 2010).   The remediation efforts in Pavlodar took place in 1997-2004. The last stage in 2000-2004 cost over 12 million USD. Since then the situation is monitored according to a special program.   The full description of mercury contamination in Pavlodar, remediation efforts, and monitoring program is in the attached 146 page file in Russian.        1) Water infiltration in ground water (30,000 people) 2) spreading in water Ishim river (20.000 people) 3) mercury dispersion in residential zone because of theft (3.000 people) (see information in details in additional notes)
health_impact: Local medics in private conversations reported about frequent and obviously toxic glomerular affection and about defects of neurologic-and-behavioral maturation.
notes: Likely Transmission Path: 1) Water infiltration in ground water. There is a constant rise of ground water level (0,07-0,12 m per year). Reasons: dangerous structure engineering  service; lack of advanced system downpour sewerage; leakage settling and plants storage; concreting natural drainage of ground water (embankment building).  2) spreading in water Ishim river Even in sampeles taken 250 km  downstream the river in Omsk district (Russia) there are considerable concentrations of mercury.  3) mercury dispersion in residential zone because of thefts. There was a collapse in USSR and industry management broke down. In that times  thefts were registered repeatedly. For example, in one Pavlodar country house it was found 114 kg of mercury in three containers. Cottage owner hid them after that he stole them from plant.  In 1999 Kazakhstan leaders addresses an appeal to France government with a request. They asked to finance thee ecological projects including a mercury liquidation project in Pavlodar. June 2000. Signing intergovernmental agreement between France and Kazakhstan government about providing Kazakhstan with a credit of 8,2 millions euro at a rate 2,1% on 16 years with favourable period of 6 years. France define assign company "BRGM" as a works contractor on Pavlodar chemical plant. Supposed two stages of solving the mercury problem. First - study of mercury spreading in soil and making a timetable of steps.Already at first stage French workers supposed to eliminate  about 1000 tones polluted soil. Than it was planned step-by-step destruction the whole hotbed of mercury pollution on termovacuum equipment.  That equipment doesn't pollute the environment. 1 Of November, 2001. On the parlament meeting prime minister of Kazakhstan K. Tokaev declared that government doesn't take any obligations on French credit. But study has been done and even free of charge. 2004. It was announced that clay wall around workshop is complete. This wall should isolate ground mercury pollution hearth.For completion this work and for mercury monitiring government has allocated 3,1 millions dollars. But specialists made there minds skeptically.  Thus, scientists of the Institute of  metallurgy and enrichment definitely reported: clay ring can't solve the problem, because the soil is dump and mercury spreading would continue - 1) evaporation from soil 2) round the ring - under the wall or over it in period of spring flood. Moreover danger increasing at the expense of percolation to artesian water. At the same time another technology using: partial utilization. The project of International scientific and technical centre of USA (2003-2006) "development of vacuum technology and equipment for cleaning polluted by mercury soil; Pavlodar chemistry plant"

name: Vindhyachal Thermal Power Plant, Sidhi, Madhya Pradesh
one_sentence: The Vindhyachal Thermal Power Plant is emitting large amounts of sulfur dioxide and is polluting the air of the surrounding area.
description: Singrauli is a small urban area with many power plant facilities because of the abundant availability of coal and water resources. The Singrauli coalfield has an area of 2,202 sq.km. The coalfields are divided into two basins - Moher-sub basin(312.2 sq.km) and Singrauli basin (1,890 sq.km).   A major part of the Moher-sub basin lies in the Sidhi district, Madhya Pradesh, and a small part of it is in the Sonbhadra district of Uttar Pradesh.   Singrauli Super Thermal Power Plant, Vindhyachal Super Thermal Power Plant, Rihand Super Thermal Power Plant, Anpura UPSEB Power Plant, Renusagar Thermal Power Plant, M/S Hindalco, M/S Hi Tech Carbon, and Konaria Chemicals are some of the power plants and other industries located in the Singrauli region. Another three plants are also being built in the area - Essar Power, Jaypee Power, and Hindalco.   Vindhyachal Thermal Power Plant is a coal based thermal power plant located in the Sidhi District of Madhya Pradesh, in the Singrauli region.   The station started power generation in 1987. It generates an average of about 2,260 million units of power annually. Madhya Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Maharashtra, Gujarat, Goa, Daman and Diu, and Dadra and Nagar Haveli are the major consumers of power generated from this plant.   There is no forest cover and the Rihand river is nearby. There are huge mountains of coal mines where mechanized open cast mining is done.    It has been discovered that the sulfur dioxide concentration in the air of this region is too high - 1,398 mg/m3.         Sulfur Dioxide is transmitted into the air. This power plant is causing severe air pollution.
health_impact: Typical health impacts of exposure to sulfur dioxide are:  Asthmatic problems, bronchitis, skin allergies, cancer, TB, etc.
notes: NA
strategy: Proper equipments to be provided Awareness programme Labour laws to be informed to the labourers
remediation_plan: Increase the chimney height Use of filter in the chimney To make green zone in and around the industry Proper monitoring of the stacks and machines For liquid fly ash, recycling unit to be constructed  Government to be involved
barriers: Political Barrier: Industrialist. politician also involved  Social Barrier: Workers working in the plant is the only source of earning. Difficult to talk and make them understand.

name: Ravi Town Lahore
one_sentence: Industrial effluents, with heavy metals, have been released into this surface water.
description: The River Ravi is by far the most polluted river in Pakistan. The river gets most polluted while flowing through the regions between Lahore and Balloki. Much of the waste products are deposited in the river which contaminates its water. The river has been reduced to a channel due to the serious and heavy pollution discharges.  Ravi River flowing through both India and Pakistan originates at the Banghal basin. The river flows at a great speed through the region but is unfortunately the most polluted river in Pakistan. Ravi waters both India and Pakistan. Since its source is in India it flows through the northwestern part of Chamba and through the southwestern part of Jammu and Kashmir. Finally it reaches Pakistan to water the land of India's neighbor. The river drains a total catchment area of 14,442 square kilometers (5,576 sq mi) in India after flowing for a length of 725 kilometers (450 mi).  The Ravi valley in its upper reaches has Deodar, walnut, Quercus ilex, daphne, mulberry, alder, edible pine (Pinus gerardiana), twisted cypress (Cupressus torulosa), chinar (Platanus orientalis), daphne papyracea, cedrela serata, and sisso, olive and kakkar (raus).   According to official studies, the Ravi is the most polluted river in Pakistan. Most wastewater discharge reaches the river in a 60 km stretch between Balloki and Lahore. The Ravi is currently estimated to receive 47 percent of the total municipal and industrial discharge pumped into all rivers of Pakistan. In addition, industrial and agricultural waste from both India and Pakistan pour into the river through the Hudaira drain, which enters the Ravi on Lahore's outskirts.  As the River has died a slow and painful death, the fishing communities that for generations made a living from its waters have suffered too. The extreme pollution of the River Ravi has destroyed most of the 42 species of fish that once lived in the river, as well as the bird life around it, which has migrated to other areas. The survival of small invertebrates, micro fauna and flora is also threatened. (WWF Pakistan)  The weather of the area is extreme. Winters are very cold and summers are very hot with temperature soaring up to 40 C, but at the time of study it was pleasant. The direction of the wind  was southwards.  The Ravi has been transformed into the river of death which is playing havoc with the health of the citizens. As many as 42 species of fish have become extinct from the river. Dumping of sacrificial meat, industrial and hospital waste on the river-beds have made the situation worse. Various pathways are involved like:  drinking of contaminated water use of groundwater and surface water for drinking and irrigating children play at polluted place inhalation of polluted air
health_impact: The results of the pollution are clearly visible. Most children who swim, dive and play daily in the waters of the river, have skin lesions, boils, rashes and infections caused by the water.  The impact on the local community of the pollution of the Ravi is immense. People are suffering serious ailments. Hepatitis, skin infections, stomach disorders and respiratory tract infections are  major health issues being faced by local residents.
notes: The Ravi has been transformed into the river of death which is playing havoc with the health of the citizens. As many as 42 species of fish have become extinct from the river. Dumping of sacrificial meat, industrial and hospital waste on the river-beds have made the situation worse.
strategy: Government and NGOs can step forward and make some policies to control pollution discharges in the river.  Provide adequate health facilities to local people  awareness campeigns can be raised in the area to educate the laymen
remediation_plan: Treatment plant installation on teh site area  a combination of phsicochemical techniques can be a better way to start the remediation  time frame: 2-3 years
barriers: The river is very long.It can be divided in patches to begin with the remedial measures  Socially as such there are no barriers in teh area,People want somebody desperately to help save them.
local_champ: PCSIR,LAHORE  EPA,LAHORE  SUMAIRA AKRAM,ISLAMABAD

name: Case Rhodia Itanhaem City - SP
one_sentence: There are 4 hotspots in the city of Itanhaem City that have been contaminated with waste produced by the company Rhodia in the city of Cubatao. The population is exposed to chemicals such as hexachlorobenzene through the contaminated soil, air, and food.
description: The Municipality of Itanhaem is a seaside town of 581 km2. In straight line it is to seventy kilometers from the center of Sao Paulo and 112 kilometers by road. The northeast (NE) is bordered by the city of Mongagua. The Southwest (SW) is bordered by the Cities of Perube and Pedro de Toledo. Among Southeast (SE) and South (S) is the Atlantic Ocean. Among Northwest (NW) and North (N) is the State Park of Serra do Mar Sierra composed almost entirely by native virgin forest. The park covers an area of Iguape even to Sao Sebastiao City, has 115 hectares, involving fifteen municipalities of the metropolitan region of Sao Paulo. In the area of the park is 800 meters high where Itanhaem makes boundary with the Cities of Sao Paulo and Juquitiba.  Itanhaem has about 72 thousand inhabitants. Like other cities of Metropolitan Area of "Baixada Santista" this population reaches three times in the holiday period that includes the months of December through February.  At kilometer 336 of the Highway Padre Manoel da Nobrega (old Pedro Taques), near the neighborhoods "Jardim Gaivota" and "Jamaica" if that have access to "Estrada do Rio Preto" (Black River Road in Latitude: S-24, 2303 / Longitude: W-46, 8958). On this road are 4 hotspots contaminated with waste produced by the company Rhodia in the city of Cubatao. These evictions were illegal in the period between 1976 and 1981. (see file in part 06: 03_site_in_blak_river_road.bmp). (DMS S24-13-49,63 / W46-56-45,82).   Km 1,8: The total site area is 20,000 m2, (focus of contamination 10 m2 the area is with wire fence. This between geographic coordinates: Latitude: S-24, 2208 / Longitude: W-46, 9086. (DMS: S24-13-15,28 / W46-54-31,93).   Km 5,0: The site is located between the geographic coordinates: Latitude: S-24, 2028 / Longitude: W-46, 9333, has total area of 15,000 m2 and where they were disposed toxic waste. The area is surrounded by canvas. (DMS: S-24-12-10,26 / W-46-56-00,09)  Km 6,2: Area located at the height of 6.2 km in Road of Black River, between the geographic Coordinates: Latitude: S-24,1961 / Longitude: W-46,9408, with an area of approximately 25,000 m2. It is estimated that approximately 100 tonnes of toxic waste were deposited illegally at this place. Toxic waste in pure form were scattered over an area of 200m2. The area is surrounded with wire netting (DMS: S-24-11-46,43 / W46-56-27,09).       Through air and direct contact with dust and contaminated soil. And food intake in the region that have been contaminated by waste from Rhodia Company.
health_impact: In spite of having various diseases and disorders that can be attributed to exposure to chlorine, there is no official study that has become public in the population who may have been exposed in the contaminated region in Itanhaem/SP.
notes: A visit to the contaminated region of Itanhaem was held in 2002. A team of about 6 people conducted surveys and some interviews with people who live close to sources of infection among which we highlight three:  1) - M. Franchacc resident for sixteen (16) years on site, located at Av Rio Preto No Itanhaem 1250, approximately 1.4 km of Highway Padre Manoel da Nobrega right toward Peruibe City:  - It took water from an artesian well until March 2002;  - Cultivated vegetable garden and consumed by 1995;  - Performed 4 miscarriages;  - Has a son named "V.Z" (three years) that he was ill, with suspect for leukemia;  - Generally said all had symptoms of itching and skin problems;  - Reported that the well water is very bad smell, some days more than others.  2) - J. Costa, who has lived for six years on the site, located at road of Rio Preto, in the proximities of School (she has a trade in place denominated Bar Vicente Romualdo Costa ME), distant about of 7.0 km of Highway Padre Manoel da Nobrega:   - They drink water from an artesian well that has a strong smell of iodine taste and irritates the throat;  - There was never water analysis;  - Has problem uterus (not detailed), the mother and sister does not have this problem;  - Children with symptoms of itching skin, (as being like a fungal infection), headaches and stomach; - The interviewee reported that children of "School Teixeira Rosa" only started receiving treated water in January 2002. They drank water from an artesian well. This time the students consumed a lot of medicine for headache, which were purchased in their trade; -- The school has 60 children and is still used water from an artesian well for other activities such as personal hygiene and cleanliness. - Also said that in general many of their friends who live nearby have similar health problems. Including one who had spontaneous abortion, but the interviewee doesn't know how to say if has relationship with the exposure to the residues.  3) - L. S. Miguel resident for three years on site stated that his wife Tatiana symptoms like fainting, vomiting, stains rocks the body. The doctor diagnosed the disease, but now that cannot afford to buy the drugs.
strategy: In all contaminated sites was removed the residue was on the ground. The contaminated areas were surrounded with wire netting.
remediation_plan: Only in Site of Coca was installed pumping the underground aquifer that is send to towers of activated charcoal for removal of contaminants. There is forecast for completion of the treatment of groundwater.  The remediation process adopted by the company it seems that is not the best option. Lack clarification appropriate technical and analytical about the process. Lack transparency and public participation in decision-making.
barriers: The biggest obstacle to success in the remediation process is the company itself. The company has an aggressive group of lobbyists that have great influence on public bodies of government, media and environmental agencies. This brings a great uncertainty about the whole process.

name: Morales, San Luis Potosi
one_sentence: Living in close proximity to a arsenic-copper smelter in Morales, residents are exposed to high levels of arsenic and lead in soil and dust, and this has lead to high arsenic-urine levels and blood-lead levels in children.
description: The state of San Luis Potosi is situated in the center of the country. It is bordered by Coahuila to the north, Nuevo Leon to the northeast, Tamaulipas to the east, Veracruz to the east, Hidalgo, Querutaro, and Guanajuato to the south, and Zacatecas to the northwest. At the 2005 census the population was 2,410,414.  San Luis Potosï¿½ is bounded on the east by Nuevo Leï¿½n, Tamaulipas and Veracruz, on the south by Hidalgo, Querï¿½taro and Guanajuato, and on the west by Zacatecas. The state lies mostly on the Mexican Plateau, with the exception of the southeastern corner of the state, where the tableland breaks down into the tropical valley of the Panuco River. The surface of the plateau is comparatively level, with some low mountainous wooded ridges.   The mean elevation is about 6,000 ft., ensuring a temperate climate. The state lies partly within the arid zone of the north, while the southern half receiving a more liberal rainfall through the influence of the Nortes, which deliver significant amounts of rain. The rainfall, however, is uncertain at the western and northern regions, and much of the state is poorly provided with rivers. The soil is fertile and in favorable seasons large crops of wheat, maize, beans and cotton are grown on the uplands. In the low tropical valleys, sugar, coffee, tobacco, peppers and fruit are staple products. Stockraising is an important industry and hides, tallow and wool are exported. Fine cabinet and construction woods are also exported to a limited extent.  At one time San Luis Potosï¿½ ranked among the leading mining provinces of Mexico, but the revolts following independence resulted in a great decline in that industry. Other common ores include  gold, copper, zinc and bismuth, as well as silver.  Morales is a community in the western part of the state capital, also named San Luis Potosï¿½. It is primarily a smelter community, and the facility processes copper and lead.  Initial studies in 1993 showed that the median arsenic concentrations in the soil and dust were very high (502.4 and 857 Î¼g/g, respectively) in downtown Morales, which is located 1.5km from the smelter.   [Dï¿½az-Barriga, F. et al. "Arsenic and cadmium exposure in children living near a smelter complex in San "Luis Potosï¿½, Mexico. Environ Res 1993; 62:242-50.]    Ingestion of contaminated soil and dust was found to contribute to 88% of children's exposure in Morales.  The daily intake of arsenic for children dwelling on non-paved streets, in the least contaminated area, was estimated to be 1Î¼g/kg per day. In the most contaminated region, the estimated daily intake was 19.8Î¼g/kg/day. The reference dose established by the EPA is 1Î¼g/kg per day.
health_impact: Regarding lead, children aged 3-6 years had the highest mean blood lead levels; furthermore, 90% of them had concentrations above 10 microg/dl (CDC's action level). Total urinary arsenic was higher in children aged 8-9 yr; however, the percentage of children with concentrations above 50 microg/g creatinine (CDC's action level) or 100 microg/g creatinine (World Health Organization [WHO] action level) was similar among different age groups.

name: Chusovaya River, Pervouralsk
one_sentence: Chusovaya River is consistently polluted by chromium producing enterprise "Russian Chromium 1915". The water is used by people living in several towns on the river for drinking and other user.
description: Chusovaya River is not very big but flows through three regions of Russia. The river originates in Chelyabinsk region, flows through Sverdlovsk region, and in Perm region joins Kama River of the Volga River Basin. The factory  "Russian Chromium 1915" is based in Pervouralsk of Sverdlovsk region. The latest biggest release of pollution was registered by local activists in May 2013. Untreated wastes were released in Pakhotka Creek that joins Chusovaya River. This is not the first and likely not last incident of pollution. In 2010 it was estimated that the factory released 1.3 million cubic meters of untreated or insufficiently treated waste water, containing 14 792 kg of chromium while total allowed volume was 583 kg for that year. The waste deposits of the factory also contain about 7 million tons of chromium containing wastes that may leak and contaminate environment.   In winter 2010-2011 the attorney of Sverdlovsk confirmed pollution of Chusovaya River by the factory. The waster water treatment facilities of the factory are old, outdated, and incapable of processing the whole volume of waste water. The concenrations of chromium in waste water exceeded the standard 20 times.   "Russian Chromium 1915" is the largest producer of chromium  in Russia. The factory operates for almost 100 years and a lot of equipment is very old. The waste storage oficially does not belong to the present owners of the factory and is not maintained properly. So nobody today is responsible for contamination coming from the waste storage site.  People fish on Chusovaya RIver close to the factory. River water is also used for drinking and watering crops.
