name: Gu Di village, Nan Dan, HeChi City, Guangxi province
one_sentence: Past gold mining activities have contaminated the agricultural soil of Gu Di village and the waters of Diao Jiang River with arsenic and cadmium.
description: Mining activities take place upstream from Gu Di village. There are 6 gold mines and 300 individual mills upstream.    The exploitation has lead to severe environmental problems.  There are large volumes of sediments in river, and the submerged farmlands and patties in Gu Di village of Bao Ping countryside have been polluted badly. The sediment mostly comes from tailings of ore concentrators from the mining.   About NanDan County/Province:  NanDan prefecture is a mountain area in HeChi city, the Northwest of GuangXi province. It produces more than 20 varieties of non-ferrous metals, such as tin, antimony, zinc, gold, silver, copper, iron, indium, tungsten and etc. It is one of the most important non-ferrous metal industrial bases in China. The total volume reaches to 11 million tons, including 1.44 million tons of tins.  DiaoJiang RIver belongs to Pearl River water system. It originates from the Southeast of NanDan prefecture, is 229 kilometers, with 3,585 square kilometers of watershed area. It passes through more than 10 townships of Nan Dan prefecture, He Chi city and Du An prefecture. The non-ferrous minerals are mainly concentrated in DaChang town and CheHe town in NanDan, which is the origin of DiaoJiang River. There are about nine owned mining companies. 65 ore dressing plants (with the daily treatment capacity of over 30 tons each) along NanDan stretch. The private ore dressing companies numbered 324 units at their peak. There are around 3000 private mining points. The total annual ore processing capacity is nearly 2.5 million tons.  NanDan stretch, originating out of DiaoJiang River, is a maze of mines and tailings. The legacy tailings are piled at will. The primitive facilities of ore dressing companies, especially that of these private companies, handle the waste rock, disposed slag, wastewater and tailings under poor management conditions, which increase the potential pollution possibilities.   In addition, due to the mining activities, large areas of the land surface are exposed. The original soil is covered by tailings or abandoned stones, which contain multiple varieties of heavy metals. In the rainy season, precipitation  creates heavy soil erosion, and some tailings or some heavy metals are leached into the DiaoJiang River, making the river red and turbid.   The waste waters from the mill and tailings have not been disposed of, and still contaminate the DiaoJiang River and farmland soils.
health_impact: Possible health impacts include vascular damage, cancer, and minor illnesses.
notes: Diao Jiang is located in Guangxi province, Nandan county, and is badly polluted. The investigators dug here for soil sections of 1.5 m length, 80 cm width, and 1 m depth. The sections were located on the riverside.
strategy: closed these concentrators
remediation_plan: Part of Nandan mining affected areas.  See Nandan.
barriers: Lack of funds the Government not concerned about the environmental  Environmental monitoring is not enough

name: Madiwala Lake,BTM 2nd Stage,Banglore,Karnataka
one_sentence: Industrial and residential runoff as well as religious idol immersion have likely contaminated this lake with Lead.
description: Bangalore also known as Bengaluru, is the capital of the state of Karnataka. Located on the Deccan Plateau in the south-eastern part of Karnataka, Bangalore is India's third most populous city and fifth-most populous urban agglomeration.   As of 2009, Bangalore was inducted in the list of Global cities and ranked as a "Beta World City" alongside Geneva, Copenhagen, Boston, Cairo, Riyadh, Berlin, to name a few, in the studies performed by the Globalization and World Cities Study Group and Network in 2008.  Today as a large city and growing metropolis, Bangalore is home to many of the most well-recognized colleges and research institutions in India.  Numerous public sector heavy industries, software companies, aerospace, telecommunications, and defence organisations are located in the city.   Bangalore is known as the Silicon Valley of India because of its position as the nation's leading IT exporter.  A demographically diverse city, Bangalore is a major economic and cultural hub and the fastest growing major metropolis in India.  The headquarter of several public sector undertakings such as Bharat Electronics Limited (BEL), Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL), National Aerospace Laboratories (NAL), Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited (BHEL), Bharat Earth Movers Limited (BEML) and Hindustan Machine Tools (HMT) are located in Bangalore.   In June 1972 the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) was established under the Department of Space and headquartered in the city.  The site Madiwala lake is one of the biggest lakes in Bangalore, India spread over an area of 114.3 hectare. It is situated in the BTM Layout in Bangalore city.   It is a home to many migratory birds. The Madiwala Lake comes under the administration of Karnataka State Forest Department.  As the city's growth spiraled, the Madivala Lake was subjected to intense pollution, with the blockage of inflow channels, immersion of religious idols,encroachments into the catchment area and inflow of sewage water.   With chemical waste being dumped into the lake by neighboring industrial units every day, the water has turned acidic.(links attached)  All these had transformed the lake into a very large sewage pool. Madivala Lake, which was once, a fresh water tank, was fully covered with thick growth water hyacinth, thus preventing aeration and affecting the bio-diversity of flora and fauna.              Water  and soil are  the likely transmission pathway as the heavy metal pollution has been found in lake water and soil samples.   Water from lake is used for washing purposes,hence regular contact with human population is there.  Fish present in the lake also reports of traces of heavy metals.  The fish from lake is sold in Madiwala market;with heavy metals presence in fish samples,the same is entering the food chain,thus seriously impacting human health.  Historically lakes in the Bangalore region were managed by a plethora of government agencies such as the Forest Department, Minor Irrigation Department, Horticulture Department, Public Works Department (PWD), Bangalore Mahanagara Palike (BMP), Bangalore Development Authority (BDA), Tourism Department, City Municipal Councils and Panchayats; each organization claiming its own jurisdiction of ownership and maintenance rights resulting in a deficient, inconsistent and uncoordinated approach   The Government of Karnataka, following the directive of The Honourable High Court of Karnataka and considering the unchecked deterioration of lakes in and around Bangalore and keeping in line with their critical role in maintaining healthy environs and recharging of ground water, set up the Lake Development Authority (LDA) in July 2002 as a registered society under the Karnataka Societies Registration Act, 1959, as a non-profit organization and a para–statal body with a mandate of  "working solely for the regeneration and conservation of lakes in and around Bangalore city within BMRDA jurisdiction in the first instance, would be extended to other parts of Karnataka subsequently"

Periodical monitoring of the water quality is thus required to assess the condition of surface water.   This will be helpful in saving the lake from further degradation. Use of toxicand nonbiodegradable chemical dyes for painting idols should bestrictly prohibited.  2.All the flowers, leavesand artificial ornaments of idols should be removed and idols may beimmersed into a corner of pond using removable synthetic liners in the bottom.   Post immersion, liners may be taken out along with remains ofidols and lime should be added to the pond water for settling the solids.  Desludging of the pond should be undertaken afterwards. name: Dilovasi Industrial Organized District, Gebze, Kocaeli
one_sentence: Uncontrolled emissions and effluents from the Dilovasi Industrial Organized District are releasing high concentrations of cadmium into the air and water of neighborhoods in the Gebze district of Kocaeli province.
description:
The Dilovasi Industrial Organized District (DOSB), a region within the Gebze district of the Kocaeli Province, is highly industrialized with few emissions restrictions in place. Its development followed Turkey's rapid urbanization and industrialization in the 1980s. Dilovasi is 63 miles east of Istanbul and is reported to house more than 170 under-regulated plants and factories. Many of these are located in the middle of residential neighborhoods like the Yeni Yidiz and Fatih neighborhoods. Industry activities include steel production, chemical manufacturing, metals processing, and factories producing paints and varnishes. 2005 figures reported by the Turkish Daily News stated that 44 percent of all factories were unlicensed, 76 percent did not have waste-disposal permits, and nearly 72 percent lacked emissions licenses. In late 2006, a parliamentary committee issued a report demonstrating that many factories were using carcinogenic products without establishing adequate protective measures. The discharge from these factories is dumped into the Dildresi River, which is further responsible for over 40% of the pollution flowing into the Gulf of Izmit and 20% of that flowing into the Sea of Marmara, according to an official at a local environmental protection association. Pollution is also directly dumped into Eynerce Creek and Dil Creek. A May 2006 study by the Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey demonstrated that the proportion of cadmium in the air is over 239 times the European Union advised limit and over 30 times the Turkish. It has been determined that those living in Dilovasi inhale a dangerously high level of toxic fumes on a regular basis. A 24-hour sample taken between April 17 and 18, 2006 and a 48-hour sample taken between April 18-20, 2006 showed markedly high levels of cadmium in the air. Levels were reported to be 1.195micrograms/cubic metre. EU standards allow for 0.005 mikrograms/cubic metre and Turkish samples allow for 0.04. A 2006 parliamentary commission report called for evacuation of the Yeni Yildiz and Fatih neighborhoods. It stated that most of the waste produced by factories in the region was hazardous to health and that industries were not taking enough preventative measures in disposal.

Coordinates: 40.7916487903, 29.5306325866 Air Although the test data deals with cadmium in the air, water is also being polluted.
health_impact: Most residents, children especially, suffer from asthma and chronic bronchitis.    A Turkish parliamentary commission report stated that most of the Dilovasi factories use and produce cancer-causing substances.  Reports by the national health, environment and industry ministries have demonstrated the linkage of high cancer rates in the region to the location of industries in residential neighborhoods.  These reports state that 32.3 percent of all deaths in the region are due to cancer, 44 percent of which involve lung cancer. The commission's report recommended the initiation of a comprehensive cancer assessment in the region.  Other reports have concluded that the death rates from cancer in Dilovasi are 2.7 times the world average and 2.6 times the Turkish.  Deaths caused by lung and stomach cancer are 2.6 times the world average; deaths from prostate cancer are noted to be 3.2 times higher.  A report by a physician at the University of Koaceli nearby quotes that "While the world average for mortality due to cancer is 12%, the rate is 30% in Dilovasi."  These same reports state that residents who have lived in the region 10 years are 4.4 times more likely to die from cancer than those who have not.
strategy: Marked no for HPF because it is in Turkey

name: Artisanal Gold Mining in Kahengyere Village, Buhwejuu County, Bushenyi District
one_sentence: Artisanal gold mining in Kahengyere Village using mercury amalgamation has caused local surface waters to become contaminated with mercury.
description: Kahengyere small scale mining is located in Kibimba Village in Rwengwe Subcounty Buhwejuu in County in Bushenyi District.Gold mining is done at the footslope and in the higly saturated wetalns system. The Mine tailings and producs of amalgamation is done in the wetland system which increases the pollution incident into the aquatic ecosystem. The entire area drains into domestic and ground water sources.The area is highly saturated with water being located very close to wetland stream and at footslope in undulating terrain. It is estimated that 30 households approximately (180 people including Children and women)  are involved in this activity. The operations are typically reliant on rudimentary methods and technology and majorly performed by miners who lack economic capital. Mercury- gold amalgamations is an inexpensive, efficient and simple gold extraction method, it is the most common method employed in this area. It is approximated that this process result into the discharge of large amounts of mercury into the adjacent aquatic ecosystems and the downstream environment.Mainly,most of the gold is recovered from alluvial deposits                     The mining and amalgamation activity have generated in situ and ex-situ  pollution incidents.Site induced Runoff and erosion drains nearby farma and water sources used by the by adjacent and downstream. Also the miner interface on a regular basis with mer

This making the tracing of its health impact on the population is equally difficult. However, mercury and its associated ecological and health effects are abstract, diffuse, and complex.Its effect on human health are many many, and are dependent on the chemical composition, pathways of exposure, length of exposure, and the individual organism exposed.Considering the fact that mercury pollution cycle is difficult to explain and its toxic effects challenging,and the fact that the ares are located in extreme remote locations with low literacy levels and language barriers there has been no country attempt to determine the detrimental level of Mercury to the population in this area.

name: Ship breaking industry, Sitakunda, Chittagong
one_sentence: A large ship breaking industry in Sitakunda is polluting the air, soil, food, and water with a large number of pollutants, primarily chromium.
description: Ship breaking (ship scrapping) has evolved as an industry in Bangladesh since 1969. The industry is principally located in the beach area of Fauzdarhat and is spread along a 16km stretch of the coastline encompassing Selimpur, Bhatiary, Sonaichhari and Kumira Unions (latitude 22 25â€² and 22 28â€²N, and longitude 91 42â€² and 91 45â€²E ) of Sitakunda Upazilla (22 22â€² and 22 42â€² N latitude and 91 34â€² and 91 48â€² E longitude) of Chittagong district (22 37â€²00â€³N 91 9â€²40â€³E 22 61â€²67â€³N 91 66â€²11â€³E).   Sitakunda Upazila occupies an area of 483.97 square kilometres, which includes 61.61 square kilometres of forest. It is bordered by Mirsharai to the north, Pahartali to the south, Fatickchhari, Hathazari and Panchlaish to the east, and the Sandwip Channel in the Bay of Bengal to the west.   The Sitakunda range is 70 kilometres long and 10 kilometres wide and is one of the westernmost ranges of Chittagong and Chittagong Hill Tracts, delimited by the Feni River in the north, the Karnaphuli River in the south, the Halda River in the east and the Sandwip Channel in the west. The Sitakunda range acts as a water divide between the Halda Valley and the Sandwip Channel. The Sandwip Channel represents the northern end of the western part of the Chittagong-Tripura Folded Belt.   The Sitakunda range is a 32-kilometre long ridge in the center of the Upazila, which reaches an altitude of 352 meters above sea level at Chandranath or Sitakunda peak, the highest peak in Chittagong District. Part of Sitakunda is covered by low hill ranges, while the rest is in the Bengal flood plain. To the north, Rajbari Tila at 274 metres and Sajidhala at 244 metres are the highest peaks in this range, which drops abruptly to a height of less than 92 metres in the vicinity of Chittagong City to the south.   Sitakunda Town, with an area of 28.63 square kilometres is the administrative center and the sole municipality (Pourashabha) of Sitakunda Upazila. The rest of the area is rural and organized into 10 Union Committees (Union Parishads), namely Banshbaria, Barabkunda, Bariadyala, Bhatiari, Kumira, Muradpur, Salimpur, Sonaichhari, Saidpur and Bhatiari Cantonment Area.   The area is divided into 69 mauzas and 59 villages. According to the census of 2001, Sitakunda had a population of 335,178 with a gender ratio of 119:100. As of 2001, the population density of Sitakunda was 693 inhabitants per square km. The average populations of administrative units are: 33,518 for unions, 4,858 for mauzas (revenue villages), and 5,681 for villages, reported by the census.   Annual average temperature is between 32.5 C and 13.5 C with an annual rainfall of 2,687 millimeters. The main occupations of the local people by industry are service (28.76%), commerce (21.53%), and agriculture (24.12%). Out of 12,140.83 hectares of cultivatable  land, 25.46% yield a single crop, 57.95% yield double and 16.59% a triple crop annually. Fishing has traditionally been an industry restricted to low caste Hindus belonging to the fisher class, although for the last decades of the 20th century an increasing number of Muslims have joined the sector. According to a 2001 survey, 4,000 people in Sitakunda were engaged in wild shrimp fry collection.   Ship-breaking was initiated in this area in 1969. The area where the ship scrapping industry is located in Chittagong used to be covered by a mangrove forest which has progressively declined with the increase in the number of ship scrapping yards over the years. In 1983 there were 32 companies involved in the scrapping industry in Chittagong. The number of companies involved had once increased to 150 (in >60 yards) and at present around 70 companies are involved in ship scrapping activities in 24 yards. Currently, this activity takes place along the coastline of Selimpur, Bhatiary, Sonaichhari and Kumira unions.  The total population of  Selimpur (35,142), Bhatiary (49,490), Sonaichhari (38,458) and Kumira (34,135) unions is 157,245. Around 25,000 workers are directly involved in ship scrapping activities and another 200,000 individuals are engaged in businesses related to the ship scrapping activities in Bangladesh.  From 2005 to 2007, more than 250 ships, with a total weight in excess of 2.5 million tons, were broken on the shores of Bangladesh. Depending on their size and function, scrapped ships have an unladen weight of between 5,000 and 40,000 tones (an average of 13000+), 95% of which is steel, coated with between 10 and 100 tones of paint containing lead, cadmium, organotins, arsenic, zinc and chromium. Ships also contain a wide range of other hazardous wastes: sealants containing PCBs; up to 7.5 tones of various types of asbestos; several thousands liters of oil (engine oil, bilge oil, hydraulic and lubricant oils and grease). Tankers additionally hold up to 1,000 cubic meters of residual oil. Most of these materials are defined as hazardous waste under the Basel Convention. health_impact: Exposure to POPs may cause acute, medium, or long-term impacts. POPs are chemicals that are highly toxic, remain intact in the environment for long periods, become widely distributed geographically, bioaccumulate through the food chain, accumulate in the fatty tissue of living organisms, and pose a risk of causing adverse effects to human populations, wildlife, and the environment.   There has been a realization that these pollutants, upon exposure of human populations, can cause serious health effects ranging from increased incidence of cancers to disruption of hormonal systems. These effects have also been observed and recorded for various animal species.   Acute poisoning, usually due to exposure to large quantities in a very short time, may lead to an increase in sensitivity and a tingling sensation in the face and limbs, giddiness, lack of coordination, tremors, and mental confusion.   If ingested, gastrointestinal irritation (vomiting and diarrhea) occur. In the case of severe intoxication: muscular contractions followed by generalized convulsions, cardiac arrhythmia due to increased cardiac irritability, and even coma and respiratory depression may occur.  Medium-and long-term effects may be observed after a single exposure to a large non-lethal dose or after repeated exposures to doses that are usually low. And they include reproductive effects (abortion, retardation of fetal growth, birth defects and increased mortality among the newborns of exposed mothers), and infertility and loss of libido (exposure to aldrin and dieldrin).   Almost all POPs are mutagenic (except mirex and toxaphene) and are considered as potential carcinogens. Chlordane, DDT, heptachlor, aldrin and dieldrin are associated with liver cancer. DDT is also associated with breast cancer and dieldrin with cancer of the adrenal glands.  Medium or long term exposure to POPs may induce loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, headaches, sleep alterations, peripheral neuropathy, liver and renal damage, cardiac arrhythmia, eye problems (allergic conjunctivitis, blepharitis, and retinal angiopathy). Personality changes and difficulties in concentrating may occur particularly in people exposed to heptachlor.  PCBs are highly toxic and persistent pollutants. They bioaccumulate and get highly magnified in the fatty tissue, especially in higher trophic levels of the food chain. Exposure to PCBs has been associated with a variety of adverse health problems. PCBs have been linked to cancer, liver damage, reproductive impairments, immune system damage and behavioral and neurological damage.  Dioxins are carcinogenic and can suppress the immune system. Dioxins are suspected to have prenatal and post natal effects on children's nervous systems. They have been linked to endocrine disruption, reproductive abnormalities, neurological problems, and infertility in both humans and animals. Moreover dioxin exposures are associated with increased risk of severe skin lesions such as chloracne and hyper-pigmentation, altered liver function and lipid metabolism, general weakness associated with drastic weight loss, changes in activities of various liver enzymes, and depression of the immune system.  Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) can have a negative impact on the environment and human health. PVC has been known to cause Raynaud's syndrome, scleroderma, cholangiocarcinoma, asthma angiosarcoma, liver cancer, brain cancer, acroosteolysis and risks of impaired human reproduction, etc.  PAHs have been shown to cause cancer in laboratory animals, and also in humans following occupational exposure at high concentrations. Some 30 compounds and several hundreds of derivatives are carcinogenic. A number of PAHs have been shown to be genotoxic (i.e. they interact with the genetic material in cells). The EU Scientific Committee on Food (SCF) identified 15 PAHs that may be genotoxic and carcinogenic to humans (SCF, 2002). PAHs cause malignant tumors by interfering with enzymatic breakdown, affecting the lungs, stomach, intestine and skin.  Organotins: TBT is considered as one of the most toxic compounds in the aquatic ecosystems. Its impact on marine organisms ranges from the subtle to the lethal. TBT is responsible for the disruption of the endocrine system of marine shellfish leading to the development of male characteristics in female marine snails.   TBT also impairs the immune system of organisms. Shellfish are reported to have developed shell malformation after exposure to extremely low levels of TBT in the seawater.   Organotins are nerve toxins that accumulate in the blood, liver, kidneys and brain. High doses of organotins have been shown to damage the central nervous system and reproductive mechanisms in mammals. The most widely used organotin, tributyltin(TBT), is an endocrine disrupting chemical in mammals. There is evidence of organotins having an endocrine disrupting effect in fish. Some recent works appear to suggest that the consumption of contaminated fish is posing a real threat to humans. Organotins also bioaccumulate in certain marine species, some of which are food species used by humans. Organotins have endocrine disrupting ability in humans. Butyltins disrupt the critical function of human immune cells, particularly killer cells. As organotin compounds particularly TBT can damage human health even in small doses.   Asbestos inhalation leads to a slow buildup of scar-like tissue in the lungs and in the membrane that surrounds the lungs. This scar-like tissue does not expand and contract like normal lung tissue and so breathing becomes difficult and this hampers the ability to exchange gases. Blood flow to the lungs may also be decreased, and this causes the heart to enlarge, thus leading to a disease called asbestosis. People with asbestosis have shortness of breath, often accompanied by a cough. This disease can eventually lead to disability or death. Exposure to asbestos may lead to cancer of the lung tissue itself and mesothelioma (cancer of the membrane that surrounds the lung and also of other internal organs). Inhalation of asbestos can increase the chances of getting cancer in other locations (for example, the stomach, intestines, esophagus, pancreas, and kidneys). Members of the public who are exposed to lower levels of asbestos may also have increased chances of getting cancer, but the risks are usually small and are difficult to measure directly.   Mercury is a toxic heavy metal that affects the nervous system. Mercury poisoning has been linked to outbreaks called "Minamata disease". This is a disorder of the central nervous system caused by the consumption of fish and shellfish contaminated with methyl mercury. Clinical manifestation differs from inorganic mercury poisoning in which the kidneys and the renal system are damaged. Young children are most vulnerable. Long term exposure to low levels can cause irreversible learning difficulties. Mercury can also cause mental retardation and delayed neurological and physical development.  Lead (Pb) is a toxic heavy metal that accumulates in blood and bones after inhalation or ingestion. Most of the lead that enters the human body accumulates in the bones. Long term exposure to lead may cause brain and kidney damage, and increased blood pressure. Young children are most vulnerable to its toxic effects. Adverse health effects of lead exposure include impaired mental and physical development, decreased heme-biosynthesis, elevated hearing threshold, and decreased IQ and serum levels of vitamin-D. Long-term exposure to even low levels can cause irreversible learning difficulties, mental retardation and delayed neurological and physical development, even death.  Arsenic is a human carcinogen.  Acute exposure to inorganic arsenic has serious adverse health effects. Exposure can result in lung cancer, cancer of the skin, intestine, kidney, liver or bladder. Arsenic has a wide range of effects: it can cause damage to blood vessels and nervous tissue; has adverse reproductive effects; and is also considered as an endocrine disruptor.  Though in small amounts (0.0007 to 0.003 mg/kg/day) Chromium is considered an essential nutrient for humans that helps normal metabolism (cholesterol, glucose, and fat), in large amounts it can be harmful. The hexavalent form of chromium is irritating and can cause acute adverse effects on the skin, gastrointestinal tract, liver and kidney. Some chrome based chemicals can cause eczema. When exposed to dust and fumes people may develop respiratory diseases such as lung cancer.  Oil is a highly volatile compound composed of mainly hydrocarbon, sulfur containing compounds, etc. Approximately 75% of the constituents of oil are hydrocarbons. Oil may cause serious damage to Seabirds, marine mammals, fish, molluscs, crustaceans and turtles, marine plants and human health.   Sea birds or diving birds that spend much of their time on or near the shore become oiled when feeding in contaminated areas. Consequently, many die due to drowning or poisoning. Other effects on the feathered creature can include: damage to the liver, lungs, kidneys, intestines, and other internal organs; pneumonia; reduction in the ability to reproduce; decline in the number of eggs laid; decreased fertility of eggs and thinner shell thickness; and disruption of normal breeding and incubating behaviors.   Marine mammals may suffer from poisoning and toxic effects due to ingestion of oil; congested lungs and damaged airways; gastrointestinal ulceration and hemorrhaging.  When oil seeps into shallow or confined waters, fish can be seriously affected. Fish eggs, larvae, and juveniles are much more sensitive to damage. Eggs may not hatch or may be totally destroyed. Fish absorb oil that is dissolved in water through their gills, accumulating it within the liver, stomach, and gall bladder. Such fish may be unfit for human consumption. Many molluscs, shrimp, and worms have a natural ability to purify themselves of contaminants, if the concentration is low or if the source has been removed.  Marine plants like kelp, marsh grass, mangroves, and sea grasses are some of the types of marine vegetation that are hurt by oil spills. Plants occupying the area between high and low tide marks are also adversley impacted. Human health may be affected by oil spills. Especially when contamination of drinking water sources take place. Food sources, such as fish and crustaceans, both marine and fresh water, may be tainted and the consumption of tainted food may cause human health problems. Oil pollution may threaten the livelihood of fishermen.  Reports on human health effects of pollutants from ship breaking industry in Bangladesh are scarce. Hossain, et al (2008) reported health effects among workers involved in ship scrapping that could be contributed to exposure of pollutants released as a consequence of ship scrapping activities. They reported that besides being affected by burns, injuries, explosions, and gas poisoning, most of the workers suffer from multiple diseases and health hazards. The workers face the problem of eye redness, tearing, burning sensation, blurring of vision and conjunctivitis, and respiratory problems. Respiratory problems among the workers include asthma, pneumonia, chest pain, cough and sputum. name: Guru Nanak Thermal Power Plant, Bathinda, Punjab
one_sentence: The area suffers from lead and possibly uranium contamination due to combustion of coal in thermal power plants.
description: Bathinda or Bhatinda (Punjabi: à¨¬à¨ à¨¿à©°à¨¡à¨¾), named after the Bhati Rajput kings, is one of the oldest cities in Punjab and the current administrative headquarters of Bathinda District. It is situated in north-western India in the Malwa (Punjab) Region. Courtesy to five artificial lakes in the city, Bathinda is also known as "The city of Lakes".Bathinda is located on the Indo-Gangetic alluvial plains. Bathinda's climate correspond to semi arid with high variation between summer and winter temperatures. Average annual rainfall is in a range of 20 - 40cm Bathinda is surrounded by 12 small and medium towns, making the city a hub of most industrial activities in the region.  Bathinda is one of the largest railway junctions of India. More lines extend from it than any other junction on the Indian Railway network. Bathinda cantonment is also said to be the largest in India. Bathinda has one of the biggest food-grain and cotton markets in India. The Multinational Corporation Pepsi processes horticultural products grown in Bathinda.  Major industries in Bathinda include, National Fertilizers Plant, two power plants: Guru Nanak Dev Thermal Plant and Guru Hargobind Thermal Plant(Lehra Mohabbat), Petrochemical Plants, Yarn & Textiles Plants, Citrus Fruit Belts and Sugar Mills. HMEL is building a Grassroots oil refinery in Bathinda.  Giana, Malkana Jajjal are the villages which exist in Bathinda, Punjab and due to industrial activity and excessive use of pesticide make them more prone to cancer and mental retardation. It is difficult to predict where the Uranium found in the area is coming from, but the most possible source is Thermal Power Plant . These plants are very near to these  villages and it may be possible source of uranium contamination.  The Guru Nanak Dev Thermal Plant ( à¨—à©à¨°à©‚ à¨¨à¨¾à¨¨à¨• à¨¦à©‡à¨µ à¨¥à¨°à¨®à¨² à¨ªà¨²à¨¾à¨‚à¨Ÿ ) at Bathinda[ is one of the three thermal power stations in Punjab (the other being at Lehra Mohabat and Ropar). It is a medium sized power station with 4 units that were started in the early 1970s and completeted in 1982. All total generate upto 440 Mw of power that meets the mammoth irrigation needs of lower Punjab.  At couple of years back the Thermal Plant's functioning, which some claim is not upto contemporary environment safety standards, has caused serious health problems, not only in Bathinda itself, but also in nearby towns and villages.  Fly ash is a particular problem.                                 Air, water, soil.  In this study, 27/113 children, who showed high uranium levels in their hair samples, live in the city of Bathinda, where the Guru Nanak Dev and Lehra Mohabbat Thermal Power Plants are.  These thermal plants produce high quantities of fly-ash from the burning of coal.  31% (almost a third) of the children tested (who are afflicted with the most severe neurological and cognitive conditions) come directly from a radius of less than 15 kms of this power plant.  More than 70% of Indiaâ€™s electricity generation is produced by coal-based thermal power plants.  The environmental impact of the coal industry and thermal power plants in Punjab can and should not be minimized or under-estimated.
health_impact: The villages in Bathinda have a high incidence of cancer, mental retardation, etc. The survey revealed that contaminated water had led to a rise in the cases of cancer, asthma, joint pain, premature greying of hair, skin diseases and, to an extent, mental impairment.
strategy: To bring down the pollution level 'Ammonia flue gas conditioning system' can be install and commissioned and Suspended Particulate Matter (SPM) level bring down to prescribe limits. A special tree plantation campaign has also been launched at the plant for environmental upgradation and which shall grow to provide a green cover to the environment. Under guidance of PAU Ludhiana, various plants have been grown in ash dyke area to avoid blowing of ash by wind. These shall also help to press ash into a compact layer. A bulldozer can also be press into service for this purpose.
barriers: Bureaucrats attitude towards situation can be a major hurdle.

name: Former Lenkaran (Marso) Pesticide Storage
one_sentence: Lankaran region was one of the largest producers of vegetables in USSR. DDT was one of the main pesticides that was used here until 1988. However, DDT contaminated soil presently exists in the soil affecting the residents that live close to proximity. The exposure pathways of concern include inhalation of dust and the ingestion of produce contaminated by soil.
description: Lankaran region was one of the largest produces of vegetables. These vegetables were directly exported to all northern countries of the Former Soviet Union. Therefore, this region was called "Union Water Melon Plantation". Pesticides were intensively applied. DDT was one of the main pesticides that was used here until 1988.  Lankaran pesticide storage is located directly on a railway line. It is not operating now. When Jangi Pesticide Polygon was established, a large amount of DDT was transported there. Despite this, a large amount of pesticides remained here without supervision. Rest of the pesticides were taken by local residents and used. However, there is still some amount of pesticides that are mixed with soil.  The areas is currently open, not guarder and used as a pasture for cattle. According to sayings, there were several cases in milks of animals found "footprints" of pesticides. However, since that time, no measures were taken to improve situation. There is no direct confirmations regarding health effects of this site, but effect of pesticides on human health are well known. We suggest these cases were simply not documented.
health_impact: We do not have documented information about the effects of this site on the health. However, effects of pesticides on human health is well known.
strategy: We suggest that bio-remediation activities with removing 50 cm soil layer would be enough to clean most of the contamination. There is growing competition between Ministry of Agriculture and the Ministry of Emergency Situations.
remediation_plan: We suggest one or two year will be enough to remove considerable part of pesticides.
barriers: We do not see any barriers for this

description: The site is located in the municipality of San Esteban, in the cordillera sector of the Valparaíso Region. name: Uravi
one_sentence: Abandoned arsenic mines, processing plants and primarily a waste dump are polluting surface waters and agricultural soils.  The cement dump sarcophagus is at risk of falling into the river and dumping 100,000 tons of arsenic.
description: The village of Uravi is high in the Caucasus mountains in north-west Georgia, in the Ambrolauri district. The village suffers from serious arsenic pollution as a result of extraction of arsenic at the quarry in Uravi and Racha Mining Industrial Complex, currently non-operational, is responsible for present arsenic contamination.   Gas exhaust from the plant was the strongest  source of anthropogenic arsenic emission and this toxin was deposited via precipitation into R. Lukhuni which in turn flows into the Black Sea. In addition, pollution also resulted from acidic waters and ore deposits flowing out of mines. This pollution affects ecology, biodiversity and marine resources of the area.  Arsenic production was actively used in the soviet period for military and civilian purposes and around 100,000 tons of waste from the mining industry were left on-site, which presently creates a serious hazard for human health.   There is a large arsenic dump (cement storage sarcophagus) above the town, but it is not completely closed and the rain water filters in and then back out into local surface waters and agricultural lands.  The cement walls of the sarcophagus sit directly next to the river and are at risk of falling into the river and spilling the entire contents of the dump into the surface waters.   Recent tests show arsenic levels in the soil around the village are 20-30 times higher than normal. Other scientific studies, from Tbilisi State Medical University, have found arsenic in the blood of local children.  There are some reports that the Env. Ministry has outlined a project for neutralization and utilization of this waste. The Minister says the government is aware of the problem, but with its economy still only 60% of what it was in Soviet times, the country just does not have the necessary resources.           Surface water, agricultural products (milk, meat, vegetables), direct exposure through soil and dust.
health_impact: Elevated blood-arsenic levels.  Researchers have concluded that young people in the valley are more likely to suffer from some illnesses, such as acute chest infections, than children elsewhere in the country. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13538604    High mortality rates in Racha, an area considered the healthiest with high longevity in Georgia. In 1989, Scientific-Research Institute of Occupational Disease and Hygiene carried out clinical-laboratory study on mining-chemical factory personnel in Racha. The study revealed poisoning in 89% of the tested. Skin cancer indicators were especially high in this area. http://www.cenn.org/wssl/content.php?id=457
notes: Dr Archil Chirakadze, head of the scientific research centre at Saint Andrew the First-Called University of the Patriarchy of Georgia, says the valley must be decontaminated. But the state cannot afford to, so telling parents of risks to their children is of little use. Remediation has not yet begun on this site. [As] in soils adjacent to territory of burning plant exceeds hundreds of mg/kg.  The Prime Minister visited the region in 2008 and confirmed that a factory would be built in Uravi in future.

name: Jajmau Industrial Area, Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh
one_sentence: Sewage and tannery waste from the city of Kanpur are contaminating the Ganges and Pandu Rivers with hexavalent chromium. These water sources are used downstream in Jajmau for irrigation and drinking. About 400 tanneries in Jajmau are adding to the pollution of the area.
description: Kanpur is the 8th largest metropolis in India and the largest and most important industrial area in Uttar Pradesh. Kanpur is situated between the River Ganga in the north and the River Pandu in the south. The total area of Kanpur Nagar district is 1040 sq km.  The River Ganga and River Pandu are the recipients of over 300 mld of the total wastewater generated in Kanpur.  Jajmau is a suburb of Kanpur. It is located downstream of the Ganga and has been receiving a large portion of the city's wastewater. It has been using treated sewage and tannery effluents for irrigation purposes since the early fifties, when raw sewage was being diluted with Ganga water and then supplied for irrigation.   Jajmau is believed to be the oldest inhabited place in the region and the main industry is the leather industry. It is home to some of the biggest leather tanneries in Northern India. Currently, there are 407 tannery units in Jajmau and the entire area consists of 20 villages and a population of roughly 30,000. The tannery waste is being transported to Rooma-TSDF.  In Jajmau, the lack of treatment facilities has led to tannery sludge being dumped on temporary sites exposed to human traffic. There are around 25 villages downstream from a cluster of 354 leather tanneries that have been severely impacted by untreated effluents from these units. Use of the polluted water for irrigation purposes and indiscriminate dumping of toxic tannery sludge has led to the poisoning of local population.  (http://www.adb.org/projects/pep/ind.asp)                                  People are exposed to chromium through water and food sources. The partially treated sewage water is being supplied to the farmlands, and hence has led to the widespread contamination up the food chain and sharp declines in agriculture.   Groundwater supply, which is mainly used as potable water, is also contaminated.
health_impact: Various skin problems (rashes, boils, pauples, vesicles, eczema, ring worm, white spot, blisters, decay of nails, advanced stages of leprosy, numbness of limbs) were documented in Jajmau alongside cases of stomach ailments, STDs,  miscarriages, dental problems, and mental retardation.   Cattle and crops were also affected.  Apart from the above problems, the following were also reported:  -Land degradation due to excessive deposition of heavy metals. -40% to 50% decline in crop yield. -Change in cropping patterns. -Decline in milk yield. -Presence of high levels of Chromium in agricultural produce and milk. -Frequent fish mortality. -Wastewater has created habitats for disease vectors.
notes: The cattle owners and farmers face difficulty in selling their milk and produce because people are aware that the milk from the Jajmau area is laced with Chromium. The affected villages have become infamous and farmers face severe social problems. Outsiders don't want to marry into these villages.
strategy: The following short-term strategies could be implemented:  Jajmau industrial area is a hub of tanneries and produces chromium containg sludge waste. In order to manage indiscriminate open dumping, segregation of waste should be done at source.  Basically, it is an industrial area so habitation should be avoided and the established community should be provided separate homes away from the industries.  Hazardous waste management facilities should be promoted with apropriate technologies.   Safe water supply should be provided by authorized agency.  ETPs should be promoted and treated waste water should be stored in small ponds to recharge ground water.
remediation_plan: The complete area requires remediation and treatment of contaminated water and soil at initial level.
barriers: Poor management

name: Ranipet, Tamil Nadu
one_sentence: This large chromium ore processing plant is abandoned and releasing chromium (tri and hexavalent) into the environment (water/soil). Leftover chromium slag has been used as a building material in local villages, furthering exposure.
description: Ranipet, a medium sized town, is 100 miles upstream from Chennai, the fourth largest urban area in India. Ranipet's problems pose a potential risk to people of the nearby city of Vellore. Factories in Ranipet manufacture sodium-chromate, chromium salts and basic chromium-sulfate tanning powder used in local tanneries. The Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TN PCB) estimates that in the past two decades one particular factory alone has dumped 1,500,000 tons of solid wastes in an open yard (three to five meters high and on 2 hectares of land and has contaminated the groundwater.  The contamination of the soil and groundwater, as well as run off from solid wastes has affected the health, resources, and livelihood of thousands of people. In a residential colony about one kilometer from the factory, three open wells, a dozen bore wells and about 25 public hand pumps have been abandoned due to high levels of chromium in the water. Agricultural land about a kilometer from the factory has also been affected. There is widespread fear that if this pollution is left unchecked, the Palar basin, the main drinking water source in the region, could also be contaminated. Indian farmers claim that the toxic waste from the nearby tanneries degrades the fertility of the land citing that " invariably, only one in five crops does well." Farmers also complain of the foul smells which emanate from the very water they use to irrigate their fields claiming that, "when we come in contact with the water we get ulcerations on our skins and it stings like an insect bite."
health_impact: Chromates have contaminated groundwater and Palar River which is the source of drinking water supply for Ranipet and Vellore.
notes: Leachate from the sludge flows about one kilometer to a lake, where it mixes with  wastewater from a common effluent treatment plant (CEPT) that treats tannery  effluents.  The water from this lake eventually drains into the Palar River basin,  five kilometers away, which supplies drinking water in Ranipet and the district of  Vellore.  In the past TCC was the largest supplier of the chemicals such as sodium  bichromate and basic chrome sulfate to Indian industries.Land in the vicinity of this legacy industry has been rendered fallow due to  contamination. Housing colonies are slated for construction here and legacy  contamination could pose a potential threat to the population who are unaware of  the areaï¿½s history.

name: Walajapet  Lake Water Polluted Site, Vellore, Tamilnadu
one_sentence: A local pond which is used for drinking water is contaminated with Chromium and other metals. The precise source is not known but thought to be local industry.
description: The site is a polluted pond in south western side of Walajapet town. Walajapet is a town in Tamilnadu. It is strategically located on the Palar River on the route between Chennai (Madras) and Bangalore. By bus, this locality can be reached in about 30 minutes from Vellore city center and in about 2.5 hours from Chennai. It is well connected both by road and railways. Walajah Road railway station is located about 4.5 km from the town, lying between Arakkonam and Katpadi junctions on the important railway route connecting Chennai to Coimbatore and Bangalore.It was the station connecting Arakonam and Katpadi, the first rail route in tamilnadu.  This town, located in the Vellore District, is considered to be the First Municipality and Taluk of Tamil Nadu, believed to have been formed in 1866. Former President and prominent Indian philosopher Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan (1888 - 1975) and noted Tamil scholar Mu. Varadarasanar affectionately called "Mu. Va" were among those studied in the Government Higher Secondary School of Walajapet that celebrated its centenary a decade ago. Neighbouring localities (Vellore city) : Arcot, Melvisharam, Ranipet, Vellore, Thiruvalam Neighbouring Towns : Arani, Arakkonam, Cheyyar, Kanchipuram, Kaveripakkam, Sholingur  As of 2001 India census[1], Walajapet had a population of 29,472. Males constitute 50% of the population and females 50%. Walajapet has an average literacy rate of 74.51%, higher than the national average of 59.5%: male literacy is 80.58%, and female literacy is 68.44%. In Walajapet, 10.86% of the population is under 6 years of age.         drinking water and food chain

The ratio of male & female workers is 90:10.Most of the workers suffer due to TB, skin rashes, breathing trouble. Most of the  women patients come to the hospital residing in and around polluted sites of Ranipet & Walajapet suffer due to uterus cancer, tumor. After consultation said cases are referred to Kanchipuram Cancer Hospital & TB Hospital in Chennai.  Every year 15-20 cases of tumor and 20-30 cases of uterus cancer are referred to the said hospital for their treatment.  Tumors form in different parts of the body like abdomen, cervical and head.  The cases of ulcer are referred to Vellore Government hospital.  Mr. A Rumugam & Govidaswamy of Siruvalaium village have been suffering from TB

Mr Ravichandran said some people use the pond water but no body drink the pond water as it has become polluted because the toxic items have been mixed with the ground and pond water through leaching from the polluted site. He also mentioned that there is no Tanneries and other units that could create the problems but the problems persist in Walajapet because of Ranipent based Chemical and tanneries and leather industries and CETP which are not functioning properly.  As there is sever water crisis in Walajapet and entire Vellore and the supply water is also salty so the community of nearby villages do mix the salty water with good water to meet their daily requirement.

name: Devgarh, Rajasmand District, Rajasthan
one_sentence: The small town of Devgarh contains many unregulated asbestos mills that are polluting the air with asbestos fiber and putting people at risk for lung cancer.
description: Rajsamand is situated at the southern tip of Rajasthan. The region is oval in shape, with a very narrow strip stretching towards the North. The district adjoins the Udaipur, Pali, Bhilwara, Ajmer, and Chittor districts. Rajsamand is located 65 km from Udaipur and was constituted on the 10th of April, 1990.  The district was named after the famous lake "Rajsamand," built by Maharana Raj Singh. The place is very well known for its marble production; it is the largest marble producing district in India.  Deogarh, or Devgarh, is an important small town that lies in Rajsamand district. It is 150 km from Ajmer, off the National Highway No 8, which runs from Delhi through Rajsamand and Udaipur.   Amphibole asbestos deposits occur sporadically  in the Deogarh region, specifically in an area extending from east of Charbhuja to northeast of Deogarh for a strike length of about 50 km. The deposits are mainly located from south-west to north-east near the villages Lalji-ka-khera, Roopji-ka-khera, Kalaguman, Tekhi, Kunwathal etc. The activities of these asbestos mills have been contaminating the air in the region.          Air is the likely transmission pathway, as asbestos fiber count has been found to be above the permissible limits.
health_impact: Several asbestos samples collected in Rajasthan were tested for their genotoxic potential through MN induction and SCE.   These indigenous asbestos produced enhanced MN and SCE registering their genotoxic nature. Different genotoxic activity of these samples could be attributed to the asbestos content and different mechanism(s) responsible for these events. Peripheral blood samples were also collected from the asbestos exposed population to assess genotoxicity through micronuclei (MN) formation.  Micronuclei levels were significantly higher in exposed populations compared to unexposed populations.  The data reveal that the exposed population is vulnerable for lung cancer, as MN is a biomarker for cancer.   The higher number of induced MN observed is in cases of exposed smokers, which clearly indicates the synergistic interaction between cigarette smoke and asbestos exposure.
notes: Mean asbestos fiber counts in these unorganized asbestos mills were 4.07-15.6 f/cc at Deogarh. Invariably, the fiber concentrations monitored by area samplers were always higher than that of personal samplers.  Briefly, asbestos fiber concentrations in the work environment of all the asbestos mills at Deogarh exceeded the permissible standard of 1 f/cc.  It is beyond doubt that workers in asbestos mills in Rajasthan are at serious risk of asbestos exposure.
strategy: All the workers should be provided with medical surveillance by the employer. Medical surveillance programme should consist of the following: 1. Pre- employment medical surveillance  2. Periodic medical examination  3. Medical examination at cessation of employment 4. Maintenance of medical records; and Health education  5. asbestos based units should get asbestos fibre monitoring done on regular basis.  6. All the organized and unorganized industries should ensure good house keeping practices to reduce the asbestos exposure.
remediation_plan: 1. Preferably complete plant machinery requires to be redesigned with proper engineering controls to reduce asbestos fibre emission.  2. Manual handling of asbestos should be reduced to minimum.  3. Fugitive emissions generated needs to be controlled.  4. Asbestos bearing stones should be stored in a covered shed to avoid fugitive emission.  5. All material transfer point should be connected to dust extraction system.

This clearly shows a lack of willing among Governmnet establishment which needs to rise to the occassion and take remedition measures immediately.

name: Huangniqiao Village, Sanjiang Street, Shengzhou City, Zhejiang Province
one_sentence: The activities from a now-closed pharmaceutical plant have polluted the surface and ground water of Huangniqiao Village with cyanide.
description: Xinchang is a prefecture in the center of Zhejiang province. The Jingxin Pharmaceutical factory is located 180 miles south of Shanghai, and was forced to shut down on July 4, 2005 when villagers rioted against pollution from the factory. They claimed that industrial effluents had turned the irrigation water into a greasy red sludge, stunted crop growth, and heavily polluted the Xinchang River. The factory was involved in the manufacturing of heart and brain blood vessel series medicines.  Still today, the surface water of Huangniqiao Village is polluted with cyanide. People around Xinchang are suffering negative health impacts.   The area has a typical subtropical monsoon climate, which is hot and rainy in the summer, when there is the prevailing south-east monsoon. The winter is cold and dry, and has prevailing northwest monsoons. Typhoons hit in summer and autumn. The annual rainfall is 1480-1530mm, and the mean temperature is 16.9-17.3C.   Water, irrigation.   Pollutants migrate by rain water leaching into the ground water and soil, and then into the food chain to humans.
health_impact: Local residents blame runoff from the pharmaceuticals plant to be behind the rise of cancer and birth defects in the area. No health studies could be found.  People with cyanide poisoning could have headache, dizziness, distraction, forgetfulness, weakness, sleep disorders, and vision loss. There are also reports of carcinogenic, teratogenic, mutagenic effects on the human body.
strategy: The government has increased the supervision of atmospheric treatment facility construction and operation .
remediation_plan: To strengthen the control of source, the contaminated sites could be taken plants of bio-remediation to help reduce cyanide in soil.
barriers: There were not sewage treatment plants in Xinchang City, because Shaoxing City hoped Xinchang and Shengzhou constructed jointly a large sewage treatment plant, because of two local authorities which would not been negotiated.

name: Tabalong River, Kalimantan Selatan
one_sentence: The Tabalong River receives mercury pollution from illegal gold mines around Mount Luntu.  Downstream, the contaminated water is used for domestic purposes.
description: Tabalong River is located in the province of Kalimantan Selatan, also known as South Kalimantan, one of four provinces within the island of Borneo. The river originates out of the Missim River, which draws from Mount Luntu. The Tabalong is also influenced by the Tabalong Kanan river.  The Tabalong is an important everyday resource to the riverine residents of southern Borneo, serving a variety of domestic purposes such as bathing, washing, and human waste disposal.   The source of this mercury pollution has been identified as the illegal artisanal gold mines around Mount Luntu.         Skin contact through bathing is the most likely transmission path.

name: Beawar, Distt-Ajmer, Rajasthan
one_sentence: Small scale asbestos mills line the length of this small town. Asbestos fibers in the air are causing serious health hazards for workers and residents.
description: Beawar or (Nayanagar) is a town in the Rajasthan state of India. It is a small but prosperous town situated amidst aravali hills.  It is an important centre of trade, especially in raw cotton, and had cotton presses and the Krishna cotton mills. It is the second largest centre of wool trade and also second largest producer of carpet grade woollen yarn in India.  The food processing industry is also well developed. Other industries of the town includes masala, mineral based units, machine based units, machine tools and accessories, pre-stressed concrete pipes, plastic products, textiles, wooden furniture and asbestos cement pipes.   It is the largest producer of cement in northern India and home to Shree cement. It is also mineral rich and has reserves of felspar, quartz, asbestos, soapstone, magnesitie, calcite, limestone, mica, emerald, granite, and masonry stone.  Fairly good reserves of barytes fluorit, wolastonite and vermiculite have also been found.  Innumerable small scale asbestos units line the length of this small town causing serious health hazards for the residents. The site is one such asbestos based mannufacturing unit in unorganised sector.         Air is the likely transmission pathway as asbestos fibre count has been found in workplace in air.
health_impact: Clinical Examination The subjects from asbestos â€“ based industries (exposed population) and control population having the similar socio-economic status were selected in this study.  Mean asbestos fiber counts in these unorganized asbestos mills were 2.0-5.09 f/cc at Beawer. Invariably, the fiber concentrations monitored by area sampler were always higher than that of personal sampler.   Briefly, asbestos fibre concentration in the work environment of all the asbestos mills, both at  Beawer, exceeded the permissible standard of 1 f/cc. It is beyond doubt that workers in asbestos mills in Rajasthan are at serious risk of asbestos exposure.   Studies both with light microscopic and electron microscopic showed these asbestos fibers are amphiboles. It is an established fact that amphiboles are much more toxic, asbestotic and carcinogenic than serpentine.  Cigarette smoking and asbestos exposure have additive or synergistic interactions in inducing cancer of the lung . The combination of tobacco smoking and asbestos exposure leads to an enormously high incidence of bronchogenic carcinoma.  About 35 % workers were smokers in asbestos-based industries belonging to organized and unorganized sectors.
notes: A general survey of unorganized asbestos units made it clear that industrial hygiene conditions are really very poor in asbestos mills, therefore asbestos mills were given study focus in particular.   Such asbestos mills are predominantly located in Rajasthan, particularly in Deogarh and Beawer which might be due to their rich natural sources of asbestos.
strategy: 1. All the workers should be provided with medical surveillance by the employer. Medical surveillance programme should consist of the following: Pre- employment medical surveillance Periodic medical examination Medical examination at cessation of employment Maintenance of medical records; and Health education  2. Workers likely to get exposed to asbestos should wear protective clothing and respiratory equipment.  3.All the organized and unorganized industries should ensure good house keeping practices to reduce the asbestos exposure.
remediation_plan: Preferably complete plant machinery requires to be redesigned with proper engineering controls to reduce asbestos fibre emission.  Manual handling of asbestos should be reduced to minimum.  Fugitive emissions generated needs to be controlled.  Asbestos bearing stones should be stored in a covered shed to avoid fugitive emission.  All material transfer point should be connected to dust extraction system.
barriers: unorganized sector asbestos units should be completely banned as they are causing serious health hazards.  However,since these units belong to influencial local and outside people strong political will is required to take action against such units.

description: Electronic waste recycling practices in Guiyu Town are heavily polluting Xinuo Village located in the west. name: Sirsiya River, Birgunj
one_sentence: Eight tanning industries are directly discharging their untreated waste water into the river. They are also dumping a large amount of chromium-mixed solid waste (skins, hides and fats) on the banks of the river and in the nearby communities.
description: Parmanipur, Birta-1 is located in Parsa District in the eastern region of Nepal. As it is located in the Terai region, the land is mostly flat. The general climate is very hot and dry. The major river system flowing through the area is the Sirsiya River, which subsequently flows across the border to India.  Eight tanning industries, namely: Standard Tanning, Progressive Leather, Everest Leather, Narayani Leather, Marium Leather, Global Leather, National Leather and Nepal Leather are directly discharging their untreated waste water into the river. Furthermore, they are also dumping a large amount of chromium-mixed solid waste (skin, hides and fats) on the banks of the river, and in the nearby communities.  Some of these industries have been in operation since 1975.  Standard Tanning produces 9,000 kg of hides per day, reportedly contaminating the river by discharging effluents.   * Surface Water - Dermal * Groundwater - Oral * Soil - Dermal * Air - Inhalation/ Dermal
health_impact: * Respiratory Problem * Skin related diseases * nasal septum perforation * dermatitis * gangrene etc  1) According to local medical shop owner (Mr. Umesh Lal Sah), a maximum number of patients are reported to have eye, skin, and waterborne diseases, and respiratory problems.  2) Mr Ram Charitra Sah, staff scientist, had visited the industries in 2003. He reported that he had a skin irritation for six months.  3) During an interview, Mr. Chowkat Ram, Mr. Mahadev Patel and Mr. Anwar Husen Hawari, locals living next to the industrial area, informed us of similar health and environmental pollution problems in the neighborhoods.
notes: Likely Transmission path continued...  Sirsiya river receives a huge amount of untreated industrial waste from the Tanning Industries.   People use the river water for several purposes: irrigation, swimming (mostly children), bathing, washing dishes and clothes.  There is a high risk of this hazardous waste water getting mixed up with the ground water, which is drawn out by the locals using tube wells and dug wells for drinking.  The overall area consists of agricultural fields, residential areas and major pathways. Most people working in the fields do not use any safety measures and come directly into contact with the soil. People, mostly children, walk barefoot.   Hazardous wastes dumped outside the industry area produce a very strong and foul odor.
strategy: * Increase awareness on pollution problem and health impacts among all stakeholders.   * Construction of a Chromium treatment plant.  * Proper dumping site development.  Key players: Local Municipal authorities, Community Dwellers, Industry owner and workers  Time frame - This can be done over a period of six months to 1 year.
remediation_plan: * Setting up an industrial zone with adequate treatment facilities  * Relocation of the industries from residential areas to such industrial zones, as per the government’s plan.
barriers: * Lack of awareness among the stakeholders on the glaring pollution problem and its severe health impacts   * Lack of social initiatives  * Lack of commitment from the concerned government agencies  * Deficiency of infrastructures and expertise  * Financial constraints

name: Dakanshu, Jansua Village, Rajpura, Patiala, Punjab
one_sentence: Heavy industry in Rajpura is dumping cadmium, lead, fluoride, and primarily mercury into a river that is used for drinking water and crop irrigation by the nearby populations.
description: Rajpura is situated nearly 36 km south east of Chandigarh, the capital city of Punjab in the district of Patiala. Besides being an important industrial town for Punjab, it also has historical importance.  Rajpura is an industrial town. There are a number of large scale industries like HUL (Formerly known as HLL) , Amrit Banaspati Company Limited, Siel Chemicals Limited, and Amber Enterpsises Limited, and there are also a large number of small scale industries.   The Dakanshu Nuallah river runs along the national highway on the way to Chandigarh, 2 km from Rajpura. The Nuallah carries all the industrial waste of industries along the way from Mohali into the waters of the Ghaggar river, which are used for drinking purposes by the residents of Patiala.  The specific source of the mercury could not be identified.                 By water, food.   Since the waters of Dakanshu Nuallah are being used by the farmers of surrounding villages, namely Jansua, Napra and Alampur, for agricultural purposes the pollutants are reaching the food chain, thus posing a serious threat to human lives as the level of Mercury has been found to be extraordinarily high in the water.
health_impact: 1. The metal concentration in the green leafy vegetables from the market was higher than the permissible limits of Indian Prevention of Food Adulteration Act (PFA), 1954. Nearly 16% of samples of palak were showing higher levels of Cd then the permissible limit of 1.5 mg/kg as per Indian Standard of Food Adulteration Act (PFA), 1954. (Summary findings of Study on concentration of heavy metals in vegetables in Patiala)  Inorganic mercury poisoning is associated with tremors, gingivitis and/or minor psychological changes, together with spontaneous abortion and congenital malformation. Monomethylmercury causes damage to the brain and the central nervous system, while foetal and postnatal exposure have given rise to abortion, congenital malformation and development changes in young children.  (Report attached)
notes: CGWB has carried out studies for chemical quality of ground water in the area. The ground water of the district is alkaline in nature. The EC in the area ranges from 687 to 4,100 Micromhos /cm. Nitrate values range between 0.40 to 200 mg/l and fluoride concentration ranges from 0.20 to 2.8 mg/l. In several places high fluoride and nitrate have been observed, thus the ground water in these places is harmful for human consumption.  High fluoride(F) content, more than the permissible limit of 1.5 mg/l, in shallow ground water is observed in several places in the district, thus making the water harmful (unfit) for human consumption. High values of nitrates, more than the prescribed limit of 45 mg/l, are also observed in shallow ground water at several places in the area.
strategy: 1. Highly contaminated  areas should  be mapped and the public be educated aboutits harmful effect on human body.   2.More canal should be laid for irrigation so that stress on ground watercan be reduced.  3.Mass awareness programme should be organized to educate the people regarding consequences of mining of ground water and need for its effective/economic use.   Public awareness programme should be arranged to make the people and industry aware about the menace of ground water pollution and dwindling ground water resources in the towns.  4. Cropping pattern in the area should be changed by growing low water consuming crops instead of paddy.
barriers: Punjab Pollution control board has to play a more proactive role as the problem is very severe,and merely releasing reports on groundwater contamination will not serve the purpose,as it concerns the lives of thousands of people of the region.

name: Ganesh Informal ULAB Recyclers, Nyamathi, Naivasha.
one_sentence: Large scale informal ULAB recycling was being conducted in a residential area in Nyamathi, Naivasha.   Large amounts of lead dust and fumes from the recycling plants was transported via air and wind and settled on soils, homes and farms on the downwind side.   The surrounding communities and workers are probably exposed to lead from battery recycling operations in Ganesh Eco Solutions in Nyamathi-Naivasha through ingestion of lead-contaminated soil dust and food, inhalation of lead fumes, and skin contact with lead-contaminated dust and soils.
description: Ganesh Eco Solutions is located in a residential area in Nyamathi, Naivasha in Nakuru County along latitude -0.78533 and longitude 36.522366667. Ganesh Eco Solutions has about 100 employees and neighbors several residences, Nyamathi shopping center, farms, churches and Nakuru-Nairobi highway. The area gently slopes and is very windy. Raw materials for operations in Ganesh Eco Solutions are used lead acid batteries which are recycled using crude methods, without any pollution controls. Recycling processes release large amounts of lead dust into the surrounding soils, buildings and plants. The company’s solid waste is buried in shallow pits dug within the area.  Employees in Ganesh Eco Solutions are constantly exposed to lead through direct inhalation of lead fumes and dust, ingestion of contaminated soil dust and food, and skin contact while at work. This is because they work without wearing any protective gear. Wind, surface runoffs and air are the major possible migration routes in this area. Wind blows the lead dust and lead contaminated soils across the nearby buildings, farms, shopping center and soils. School children, workers and residents in the neighborhood can inhale the lead fumes or dust from Ganesh Eco Solutions, ingest the lead-contaminated food, soil and dust.  Young children can come into skin contact with the lead or ingest the contaminated soils and dust while playing.
health_impact: High blood lead levels have been recorded among local residents as evidence in blood tests conducted by a local NGO.
notes: None.
barriers: None.

People would get exposed to heavy metals and other contaminants via dermal contact, inhalation, and ingestion. Three measurements were carried out, pollutants such as Manganese and Barium were found in high concentrations.
description: The Suape Industrial Port Complex, located 40 km south of Recife, in the municipalities of Ipojuca and Cabo de Santo Agostinho, occupies an area of 13,500 hectares, divided into four zones: port, industrial, administrative and ecological and cultural preservation. With the increase of urbanization the residences and commerce are increasingly closer to the industrial complex. During the field visit measurements were made at some points on the Guinness Armínio Highway, much of the stretch is paved.    O Complexo Industrial Portuário de Suape, localizado a 40 km ao sul do Recife, nos municípios de Ipojuca e Cabo de Santo Agostinho, ocupa uma área de 13.500 hectares, dividida em quatro zonas: portuária, industrial, administrativa e de preservação ecológica e cultural. name: Tannery 3 in Caruaru/ PE
one_sentence: This site is in the VIGISOLO database. It used to be the location of an old tannery that ended its activities in the 1990s. There´s no information that the soil has been remediated. We visited the site with an officer from the Caruaru Secretary of Health. Streets are unpaved and people can get exposed by dermal contact of by inhalation.
